If Buyer's inspections reveal contamination or other issues that trigger reporting obligations or remediation requirements, Seller may bear responsibility even though Buyer's activities initiated the discovery.
p_39.model_instructions: Narrow the carve-out: 'except to the extent arising out of (a) the mere discovery of any pre-existing condition at the Property that Buyer did not exacerbate, disturb, or release during its Inspections, provided that Buyer complied with all applicable laws in conducting such Inspections and promptly notified Seller of any such discovery.' Consider adding: 'For the avoidance of doubt, Buyer shall indemnify Seller for any costs or liabilities arising from any governmental reporting obligations triggered solely by Buyer's inspection activities.'
p_39.problematic_text: except to the extent arising out of (a) the mere discovery of any pre-existing condition at the Property
p_39.title: Pre-Existing Condition Discovery Carve-Out
p_39.user_recommendation: Clarify that carve-out applies only to conditions not exacerbated by Buyer.

p_39.description: The inspection indemnification obligation 'shall survive termination of this Agreement' without any time limitation. This creates perpetual exposure for Buyer, but more importantly for Seller, it means Seller must pursue any claims against Buyer indefinitely. Consider whether a defined survival period would be more practical for both parties.
p_39.model_instructions: While unlimited survival favors Seller, a defined period may be more practical: 'This obligation shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of two (2) years; provided, however, that such survival period shall be extended with respect to any claim for which Seller has provided written notice to Buyer prior to the expiration of such two-year period until such claim is finally resolved.'
p_39.problematic_text: This obligation shall survive termination of this Agreement.
p_39.title: Unlimited Survival of Indemnification
p_39.user_recommendation: Consider adding a reasonable survival period of 2-3 years.

p_40.description: The $1,000,000 commercial general liability insurance requirement may be inadequate for a commercial property of significant value. If Buyer's inspections cause substantial damage (e.g., environmental contamination from Phase II testing, structural damage, fire), this limit may not fully cover Seller's losses. The clause does not require umbrella or excess coverage, property damage coverage, or environmental liability coverage for invasive testing.
p_40.model_instructions: Revise the insurance requirement to increase the minimum coverage amount to at least $2,000,000 (or higher based on property value), and add requirements for: (i) umbrella/excess liability coverage of at least $5,000,000, (ii) property damage coverage, and (iii) pollution/environmental liability coverage if any invasive testing is contemplated. Also specify that coverage must be primary and non-contributory.
p_40.problematic_text: commercial general liability (occurrence) insurance in an amount no less than $1,000,000
p_40.title: Insurance Limit May Be Insufficient
p_40.user_recommendation: Increase minimum coverage to $2-5M and require environmental liability coverage.

p_40.description: The clause only requires Seller and its property manager to be listed as additional insureds. This may leave other parties with an interest in the Property (such as Seller's lender, asset manager, or other affiliated entities) without coverage protection from Buyer's inspection activities.
p_40.model_instructions: Expand the additional insured requirement to read: 'that lists Seller, Seller's property manager, Seller's lender(s) and their servicers, and their respective Affiliates, members, managers, officers, directors, employees and agents as additional insureds.'
p_40.problematic_text: that lists Seller and its property manager as additional insureds
p_40.title: Additional Insureds List Incomplete
p_40.user_recommendation: Expand additional insureds to include Seller's lender and affiliates.

p_41.description: The restoration obligation requires Buyer to restore the Property to 'substantially the same condition' which is a subjective standard that could lead to disputes about what constitutes adequate restoration. Additionally, there is no timeframe specified for completing restoration, no requirement for Seller approval of restoration work, and no remedy if Buyer fails to properly restore.
p_41.model_instructions: Revise the restoration obligation to add specificity: 'Buyer shall, within ten (10) days after termination (or such longer period as reasonably necessary with Seller's approval), restore the Property and Improvements to the same condition in which the same were found before any such entry, to Seller's reasonable satisfaction. Such restoration shall include, without limitation, filling all test holes, removing all equipment and materials, repairing any damage to landscaping, structures, or improvements, and remediating any environmental conditions caused by Buyer's activities. If Buyer fails to complete such restoration within the required timeframe, Seller may complete the restoration at Buyer's sole cost and expense, which amounts shall be due immediately upon demand.'
p_41.problematic_text: Buyer shall restore the Property and Improvements to substantially the same condition in which the same were found before any such entry upon the Property and Inspections were undertaken
p_41.title: Subjective Restoration Standard
p_41.user_recommendation: Add objective standards, timeframe, and Seller approval requirements for restoration.

p_41.description: While Buyer has obligations to pay inspection costs, prevent liens, and restore the Property, there is no mechanism to ensure Buyer has the financial ability to satisfy these obligations after termination. The Earnest Money Deposit may be refunded to Buyer upon termination, leaving Seller with only an unsecured claim against Buyer.
p_41.model_instructions: Add the following provision: 'Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this Agreement, if this Agreement terminates prior to Closing for any reason other than Seller default, Seller may retain from any refund of the Earnest Money Deposit an amount reasonably estimated by Seller to cover any outstanding restoration obligations, unpaid inspection costs, or lien claims. Any amounts so retained in excess of actual costs shall be refunded to Buyer within thirty (30) days after Seller's determination that all such obligations have been satisfied.'
p_41.problematic_text: Buyer shall promptly pay when due all costs of all Inspections done with regard to the Property and shall not permit any liens to attach to the Property
p_41.title: No Security for Restoration/Lien Obligations
p_41.user_recommendation: Allow Seller to retain portion of deposit or require bond for restoration obligations.

p_42.description: While the clause supersedes the Prior Early Access Agreement and subjects prior activities to Section 3.4, it does not clearly address whether Buyer's indemnification obligations under Section 3.4.3 apply retroactively to activities conducted under the Prior Early Access Agreement. If the prior agreement had lesser protections, there may be a gap in coverage for claims arising from those earlier activities.
p_42.model_instructions: Add clarifying language: 'For the avoidance of doubt, Buyer's indemnification obligations under Section 3.4.3 and all other obligations under this Section 3.4 shall apply to all activities undertaken by Buyer and Buyer's Due Diligence Team under any Prior Early Access Agreement as if such activities had been undertaken under this Agreement, regardless of when such activities occurred.'
p_42.problematic_text: all other activities undertaken by Buyer, Buyer's Affiliates or their employees, agents, contractors, consultants and representatives under such Prior Early Access Agreement shall be deemed governed by this Section 3.4
p_42.title: Prior Access Agreement Liability May Be Unclear
p_42.user_recommendation: Clarify that indemnification applies retroactively to prior access activities.

p_43.description: The provision obligates Seller to schedule tenant interviews but does not provide Seller with any right to be present during such interviews, to limit the scope or topics of discussion, or to review/approve questions in advance. This could allow Buyer to make representations to tenants, discuss lease terms, or otherwise interfere with Seller's tenant relationships. Additionally, 'good faith, diligent efforts' is a lower standard than 'best efforts.'
p_43.model_instructions: Revise the provision to read: 'Seller shall use good faith efforts to schedule an interview between Buyer and those Tenants designated by Buyer (subject to Seller's reasonable approval), to be held on mutually-convenient dates within the first 15 days after the Effective Date. Seller or Seller's property manager shall have the right, but not the obligation, to be present at all such interviews. Buyer agrees that during any such interviews, Buyer shall not: (i) make any representations or commitments to Tenants regarding future operations, ownership, or lease terms; (ii) discuss any matters outside the scope of confirming information contained in tenant estoppels; or (iii) disparage Seller or its management of the Property.'
p_43.problematic_text: Seller shall use good faith, diligent efforts to schedule an interview between Buyer and those Tenant designated by Buyer
p_43.title: No Limits on Tenant Interview Scope or Seller Presence
p_43.user_recommendation: Add Seller's right to attend interviews and restrict discussion topics.

p_43.description: The 15-day window for scheduling tenant interviews may be challenging if tenants have busy schedules or are uncooperative. While Seller only has a 'good faith efforts' obligation, disputes could arise about whether Seller made sufficient efforts if interviews cannot be scheduled within this timeframe.
p_43.model_instructions: Add clarifying language: 'Seller's obligation hereunder shall be deemed satisfied if Seller promptly contacts Tenants to request interviews and coordinates scheduling in good faith, regardless of whether such interviews actually occur within the specified timeframe due to Tenant unavailability or non-cooperation.'
p_43.problematic_text: within the first 15 days after the Effective Date
p_43.title: Short Window for Scheduling Interviews
p_43.user_recommendation: Consider extending window or clarifying Seller's efforts are sufficient if tenants unavailable.

p_44.description: The optional provision requires Buyer to deliver due diligence materials to Seller upon termination (except for Seller default), but these materials come 'without representation or warranty by Buyer, express or implied, as to the assignability, content, completeness or accuracy.' This means Seller could receive defective reports (e.g., a flawed Phase I environmental report) and have no recourse against Buyer if Seller relies on them. Moreover, by receiving these materials, Seller may become charged with knowledge of issues identified therein, potentially creating disclosure obligations to future buyers.
p_44.model_instructions: This optional provision may create more risk than benefit for Seller. Consider deleting entirely. If retained, revise to add: 'Buyer shall use commercially reasonable efforts to cause each third-party consultant that prepared such materials to consent to Seller's reliance thereon, and shall assign to Seller, without recourse, any warranties or indemnities running from such consultants with respect to such materials. Seller's receipt of such materials shall not, by itself, be deemed to constitute Seller's knowledge of matters contained therein for purposes of any disclosure obligations.'
p_44.problematic_text: which shall be delivered without representation or warranty by Buyer, express or implied, as to the assignability, content, completeness or accuracy of such materials of any kind whatsoever
p_44.title: Seller Receives Materials Without Protection
p_44.user_recommendation: Either delete this optional provision or require Buyer to assign consultant warranties.

p_44.description: The provision excludes 'internal reports, analyses or communications' from the delivery requirement. This could allow Buyer to withhold valuable synthesized analysis of the Property's condition, value conclusions, or identified issues that would be useful to Seller in marketing to future buyers.
p_44.model_instructions: Narrow the exclusion to read: '(excluding any internal communications protected by attorney-client privilege or work product doctrine)' to ensure Seller receives the benefit of substantive third-party analysis.
p_44.problematic_text: (excluding any internal reports, analyses or communications)
p_44.title: Buyer Retains Potentially Useful Analysis
p_44.user_recommendation: Consider narrowing exclusion to only privileged attorney communications.

p_46.description: If the Title Company fails to deliver the Title Commitment and Title Documents by the Title Commitment Delivery Date, the Due Diligence Deadline automatically extends day-for-day. This creates significant risk for Seller because: (1) the delay may be entirely outside Seller's control since Title Company is a third party, (2) there is no cap on how long this extension can last, (3) Buyer retains its free termination right during the extended period, and (4) Seller has no ability to cure or limit this exposure. Buyer could potentially use a slow Title Company delivery as a mechanism to extend its free look period indefinitely.
p_46.model_instructions: Revise the extension provision to include a cap on the automatic extension period. Replace the automatic day-for-day extension language with: 'If Buyer does not receive the Title Commitment and Title Documents by the Title Commitment Delivery Date, the Due Diligence Deadline Date (as defined in Section 1.4 above) shall be extended on a day for day basis for each day of delay in receiving the Title Commitment and Title Documents; provided, however, that in no event shall such extension exceed ten (10) Business Days. If the Title Commitment and Title Documents are not received within ten (10) Business Days after the Title Commitment Delivery Date, Buyer's sole remedy shall be to terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Earnest Money Deposit, or to proceed with the transaction.'
p_46.problematic_text: If Buyer does not receive the Title Commitment and Title Documents by the Title Commitment Delivery Date, the Due Diligence Deadline Date (as defined in Section 1.4 above) shall be extended on a day for day basis for each day of delay in receiving the Title Commitment and Title Documents.
p_46.title: Automatic Due Diligence Extension for Title Delay
p_46.user_recommendation: Cap the automatic extension at 5-10 days maximum.

p_46.description: Seller's obligation is merely to 'request' that the Title Company make the Title Commitment available. While this appropriately limits Seller's obligation to matters within its control, there is no corresponding protection for Seller if the Title Company delays. Combined with the automatic extension provision, Seller bears the risk of third-party delay without having made any performance guarantee.
p_46.model_instructions: After 'Seller shall request Title Company to make available to Buyer' add: ', and Buyer shall cooperate with Seller and Title Company to facilitate prompt delivery of such items. Buyer agrees to promptly provide any information reasonably requested by Title Company to complete the Title Commitment.'
p_46.problematic_text: Seller shall request Title Company to make available to Buyer
p_46.title: Seller Only Required to 'Request' Title Commitment
p_46.user_recommendation: Add language requiring Buyer to cooperate in expediting title delivery.

p_48.description: Unless Buyer timely objects, all Exceptions disclosed in the Title Commitment automatically become Permitted Exceptions. While this is standard, the language also sweeps in 'any other encumbrances which affect Buyer's title to the Property set forth in the Title Commitment.' This broad catch-all could inadvertently waive Seller's obligation to deliver clear title on matters that should not become Permitted Exceptions. From Seller's perspective, this is generally favorable, but the language should be reviewed for clarity.
p_48.model_instructions: No changes recommended - this deemed approval mechanism favors Seller by limiting the universe of objectionable title matters if Buyer fails to timely object. Consider whether additional specificity would strengthen the deemed approval provision.
p_48.problematic_text: all such Exceptions and any other encumbrances which affect Buyer's title to the Property set forth in the Title Commitment shall be deemed to be approved by Buyer
p_48.title: Broad Deemed Approval of Title Exceptions
p_48.user_recommendation: This provision favors Seller - consider retaining as drafted.

p_48.description: Seller is mandatorily obligated to cause release of 'any monetary Exceptions created by or through Seller which are secured by the Property.' This is a broad mandatory cure obligation with no dollar cap and no materiality threshold. If there are unexpected liens, mechanics liens filed by Seller's contractors, judgment liens, or other monetary encumbrances, Seller must clear them regardless of cost. This could create significant unexpected closing costs for Seller.
p_48.model_instructions: Modify the mandatory cure provision to include a cap. Replace the relevant portion with: 'Seller shall be obligated at Closing to cause the release of (x) any monetary Exceptions created by or through Seller which are secured by the Property, provided that Seller's aggregate obligation to cure monetary Exceptions under this clause (x) shall not exceed $250,000 (exclusive of any existing financing which Seller is otherwise required to pay off or which is being assumed by Buyer); if the cost to cure such monetary Exceptions exceeds $250,000, Seller may elect to either (A) cure such Exceptions at Seller's expense, or (B) notify Buyer, in which case Buyer may elect within five (5) Business Days to either (i) waive such Exceptions and proceed to Closing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement and receive a return of the Earnest Money Deposit'.
p_48.problematic_text: Seller shall be obligated at Closing to cause the release of (x) any monetary Exceptions created by or through Seller which are secured by the Property
p_48.title: Seller Obligated to Cure All Monetary Exceptions
p_48.user_recommendation: Add a dollar cap on Seller's mandatory cure obligations.

p_48.description: Seller must respond to Buyer's Title Objections by the sooner of (a) 5 Business Days after receipt of Buyer's notice, or (b) 3 Business Days prior to the Due Diligence Deadline. If Buyer waits until near the Title Objection Date to deliver objections, Seller may have only 3 Business Days or less to evaluate potentially complex title matters and determine which objections it will elect to cure. This compressed timeline disadvantages Seller.
p_48.model_instructions: Replace the response timeline with: 'No later than five (5) Business Days after receipt of Buyer's notice (and the Due Diligence Deadline shall be extended as necessary to provide Seller with such five (5) Business Day period), Seller shall notify Buyer in writing of those Title Objections that Seller elects to remove'. This ensures Seller always has adequate time to evaluate title objections.
p_48.problematic_text: No later than the sooner of (a) 5 Business Days after receipt of Buyer's notice, or (b) 3 Business Days prior to the Due Diligence Deadline, Seller shall notify Buyer in writing of those Title Objections that Seller elects to remove
p_48.title: Compressed Timeline for Seller Response to Title Objections
p_48.user_recommendation: Extend Seller's response period to at least 5 Business Days in all cases.

p_49.description: If new title exceptions appear after the initial Title Objection Date and Seller elects not to cure them, Buyer can terminate the Agreement and receive a full refund of the Earnest Money Deposit. This creates ongoing termination risk for Seller throughout the contract period, even after the Due Diligence Deadline has passed and the Earnest Money has gone hard. New exceptions could arise from Title Company searches, surveys, or other matters, giving Buyer a potential exit mechanism late in the transaction.
p_49.model_instructions: Add a materiality threshold to limit Buyer's termination right. Modify to read: 'If Seller does not elect to cure the New Title Objection, then Buyer's sole options shall be either (a) to accept the disapproved New Title Objection as a Permitted Exception, or (b) if such New Title Objection would have a material adverse effect on Buyer's intended use or the value of the Property (a reduction in value of more than $500,000), by written notice to Seller within 5 Business Days of Seller's election of non-removal, to terminate this Agreement, in which case the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer within 2 Business Days after termination. For any New Title Objection that does not meet the foregoing materiality threshold, Buyer's sole option shall be clause (a) above.'
p_49.problematic_text: If Seller does not elect to cure the New Title Objection, then Buyer's sole options shall be either (a) to accept the disapproved New Title Objection as a Permitted Exception, or (b) by written notice to Seller within 5 Business Days of Seller's election of non-removal, to terminate this Agreement, in which case the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer within 2 Business Days after termination.
p_49.title: Buyer Termination Right for New Title Exceptions
p_49.user_recommendation: Limit termination right to material new exceptions only.

p_49.description: The provision states that 'the Closing Date shall be extended to accommodate the time periods established in this Section 4.4.' This gives Buyer an automatic extension of the Closing Date whenever new title exceptions arise, with no cap on the length of extension. This could delay closing significantly and is entirely within Buyer's control since Buyer decides whether to object to new exceptions.
p_49.model_instructions: Modify the closing extension provision to add a cap: 'To the extent necessary, the Closing Date shall be extended to accommodate the time periods established in this Section 4.4; provided, however, that in no event shall such extension exceed fifteen (15) Business Days in the aggregate for all New Title Objections arising under this Section 4.4.'
p_49.problematic_text: To the extent necessary, the Closing Date shall be extended to accommodate the time periods established in this Section 4.4.
p_49.title: Automatic Closing Date Extension for New Exceptions
p_49.user_recommendation: Cap the automatic closing extension at 15 Business Days total.

p_49.description: If Buyer fails to act within 5 Business Days of receipt of Seller's election not to remove a New Title Objection, Buyer is deemed to have accepted the exception as a Permitted Exception. This is favorable to Seller as it prevents Buyer from holding the transaction hostage through inaction.
p_49.model_instructions: No changes recommended. This deemed acceptance provision protects Seller by ensuring that Buyer's inaction results in acceptance of the exception rather than continued uncertainty.
p_49.problematic_text: Buyer's failure to act within 5 Business Days of receipt of Seller's election not to remove a New Title Objection shall be deemed an election under clause (a) to accept the disapproved New Title Objection as a Permitted Exception.
p_49.title: Deemed Acceptance on Buyer Inaction - Favorable to Seller
p_49.user_recommendation: No changes recommended - this provision favors Seller.

p_51.description: Seller is obligated to execute 'such affidavits and other documents as the Title Company customarily or reasonably requires to issue extended coverage.' This is an open-ended obligation that allows the Title Company to require additional documents at closing. While the 'customarily or reasonably' qualifier provides some protection, Title Companies sometimes require extensive owner affidavits with representations that could expose Seller to liability.
p_51.model_instructions: Modify to add Seller approval right: 'Seller shall execute and deliver to the Title Company on or before Closing such affidavits and other documents as the Title Company customarily or reasonably requires to issue extended coverage, provided that such affidavits and documents shall be in form and substance reasonably acceptable to Seller and shall not require Seller to make any representations beyond those expressly set forth in this Agreement or expand Seller's liability beyond the limitations set forth herein ("Owner's Title Affidavit").'
p_51.problematic_text: Seller shall execute and deliver to the Title Company on or before Closing such affidavits and other documents as the Title Company customarily or reasonably requires to issue extended coverage
p_51.title: Seller Must Execute 'Customarily Required' Documents
p_51.user_recommendation: Add that required documents must be in form reasonably acceptable to Seller.

p_53.description: The representations are made both 'as of the Effective Date and as of Closing,' which means Seller must ensure all representations remain accurate at Closing, even if circumstances change due to events beyond Seller's control during the contract period. This creates exposure for Seller if market conditions, tenant situations, or third-party actions cause a representation to become inaccurate between signing and closing.
p_53.model_instructions: Revise the introductory language to state that representations are made as of the Effective Date only, with a limited bring-down certificate at Closing confirming that Seller has no actual knowledge of any material breach. Alternatively, add language stating that representations made as of Closing shall be subject to any changes disclosed to Buyer in writing prior to Closing, which changes shall not constitute a breach if Buyer proceeds to Closing.
p_53.problematic_text: as of the Effective Date and as of Closing
p_53.title: Representations Made at Two Time Points
p_53.user_recommendation: Limit representations to Effective Date only with bring-down to Seller's knowledge at Closing.

p_54.description: This representation is stated in absolute terms without any knowledge qualifier. While status representations are typically factual, if there is any administrative issue with the entity's good standing that Seller is unaware of (e.g., a filing error by the Secretary of State), Seller could be in technical breach.
p_54.model_instructions: Consider adding a proviso that allows Seller a reasonable cure period (e.g., 10 business days) to remedy any administrative deficiencies in its good standing status that may be identified prior to Closing, provided such deficiencies do not materially impact Seller's ability to convey the Property.
p_54.problematic_text: Seller is a Delaware limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing
p_54.title: Absolute Status Representation Without Qualification
p_54.user_recommendation: Add ability to cure administrative issues discovered before Closing.

p_55.description: The representation that 'this Agreement constitutes the legal, valid and binding obligation of Seller' is stated broadly. While standard, combined with the dual timing in p_53, this creates ongoing exposure. Additionally, the phrase 'have been or will be duly authorized' is forward-looking and could create issues if internal approvals are delayed.
p_55.model_instructions: Revise to state that authorization 'has been' (not 'will be') duly obtained as of execution, ensuring Seller has completed all necessary internal approvals before signing. Confirm the existing carve-outs for 'equitable principles and principles governing creditors' rights generally' are adequate, and consider adding specific carve-outs for applicable bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, moratorium, and similar laws affecting creditors' rights.
p_55.problematic_text: have been or will be duly authorized by all necessary action on the part of Seller and this Agreement constitutes the legal, valid and binding obligation of Seller
p_55.title: Binding Obligation Representation Potentially Overreaching
p_55.user_recommendation: Confirm authorization is complete at signing; add standard enforceability exceptions.

p_56.description: This representation states absolutely that no consent is required from any 'person or entity' for Seller to perform. This is extremely broad and could include consents that are unknown to Seller or that arise from third-party agreements. If any consent is later discovered to be required, Seller would be in breach regardless of Seller's knowledge or the materiality of such consent.
p_56.model_instructions: Revise to add a knowledge qualifier: 'To Seller's Knowledge, no consent, waiver, approval or authorization is required from any person or entity...' Also add a materiality qualifier: '...that would materially impair Seller's ability to perform its obligations hereunder or consummate the transactions contemplated hereby.' This protects Seller from technical breaches involving minor or unknown consent requirements.
p_56.problematic_text: No consent, waiver, approval or authorization is required from any person or entity (that has not already been obtained)
p_56.title: Absolute No-Consent Representation Creates Trap
p_56.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and materiality threshold to consent representation.

p_57.description: This representation is extremely broad, covering all judgments, orders, regulations, organizational documents, notes, mortgages, leases, and 'any lease or other material agreement or instrument.' The breadth creates significant exposure if any unknown encumbrance, judgment, or contractual restriction exists. The lack of a knowledge qualifier means Seller warrants against matters it may have no way of knowing about.
p_57.model_instructions: Add a knowledge qualifier at the beginning: 'To Seller's Knowledge, the execution and delivery...' Also consider limiting the scope to 'material' judgments, orders, or violations that would 'materially and adversely affect' the transaction. Additionally, for agreements and instruments, limit to those 'to which Seller is a party and of which Seller has actual knowledge' rather than broad constructive knowledge.
p_57.problematic_text: will not violate any judgment, order, injunction, decree, regulation or ruling of any court or the various state, local and federal governmental agencies having jurisdiction over Seller, the Property or any portion thereof
p_57.title: Sweeping Non-Contravention Representation
p_57.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and limit to agreements actually known to Seller.

p_57.description: The phrase 'any lease or other material agreement or instrument to which Seller is a party' creates exposure related to tenant leases. If any tenant lease contains a consent requirement, right of first refusal, or transfer restriction that Seller overlooked, this representation would be breached. This should be coordinated with the Leases representation in Section 5.1.15.
p_57.model_instructions: Add clarifying language that, with respect to tenant leases, Seller's representation is subject to and limited by the specific representations made in Section 5.1.15 regarding Leases. Add a knowledge qualifier or reference to disclosed documents: 'except as may be disclosed in the tenant leases delivered to Buyer pursuant to Section 3.3.'
p_57.problematic_text: any lease or other material agreement or instrument to which Seller is a party or by which it is bound
p_57.title: Reference to Any Lease Creates Tenant Agreement Exposure
p_57.user_recommendation: Cross-reference to Lease representation; add knowledge qualifier for tenant lease matters.

p_58.description: This representation extends far beyond Seller itself to include all Affiliates, partners, members, shareholders, equity owners, employees, officers, directors, representatives, and agents. Seller cannot reasonably verify OFAC compliance for all these individuals, particularly employees and agents who may number in the dozens or hundreds. This creates potential liability for circumstances entirely outside Seller's knowledge or control.
p_58.model_instructions: Revise to narrow the scope of covered persons. Replace the broad language with: 'Neither Seller nor any of its direct members or managers who hold a 10% or greater ownership interest in Seller is, nor will they become, a person or entity...' This limits the representation to parties Seller can actually verify and control.
p_58.problematic_text: Neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates, nor any of its respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners, and none of its respective employees, officers, directors, representatives or agents
p_58.title: Overly Broad OFAC Representation Scope
p_58.user_recommendation: Limit representation to Seller and its direct controlling members/managers.

p_58.description: The representation includes forward-looking language ('nor will they become') that commits Seller to a future state it cannot guarantee. OFAC lists are updated regularly, and Seller has no control over whether a person becomes designated after Closing. This creates ongoing exposure beyond Closing for circumstances Seller cannot predict or prevent.
p_58.model_instructions: Delete the forward-looking language 'nor will they become' and revise to read: 'Neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates... is, as of the Closing Date, a person or entity with whom United States persons or entities are restricted from doing business...' This limits the representation to a point-in-time statement rather than an ongoing guarantee.
p_58.title: Future Compliance Guarantee Is Risky
p_58.user_recommendation: Limit the representation to the current state as of Closing only.

p_58.description: Unlike other representations in this agreement (see 5.1.7, 5.1.9, 5.1.10), this OFAC representation is stated as an absolute fact without any knowledge qualifier. Seller is making an unqualified guarantee about the OFAC status of potentially dozens or hundreds of people, which Seller cannot verify with certainty.
p_58.model_instructions: Add the knowledge qualifier consistent with Section 5.2's definition. Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates, nor any of its respective members or managers, is a person or entity...' This aligns with the knowledge standard used elsewhere in the agreement and limits Seller's exposure to matters it can actually verify.
p_58.problematic_text: Neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates, nor any of its respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners, and none of its respective employees, officers, directors, representatives or agents is
p_58.title: No Knowledge Qualifier on OFAC Representation
p_58.user_recommendation: Add 'to Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

p_59.description: The bankruptcy representation is stated as absolute fact. While Seller should generally know its own bankruptcy status, the representation could be qualified to align with other representations and provide consistent protection. This is a minor risk as Seller should have actual knowledge of these matters.
p_59.model_instructions: This is informational only. The current language is market-standard for bankruptcy representations. If desired for consistency, could add: 'To Seller's knowledge, Seller has not...' but this is not strictly necessary as Seller should have actual knowledge of its own bankruptcy status.
p_59.title: Bankruptcy Representation Lacks Knowledge Qualifier
p_59.user_recommendation: Consider adding knowledge qualifier for consistency, though risk is low.

p_60.description: The first clause of this representation (regarding actions that would affect Seller's ability to perform) is stated without a knowledge qualifier, making it an absolute representation. While Seller should know of actions it is a party to, the breadth of 'governmental investigation' could catch matters Seller is unaware of. The knowledge qualifier only applies to the second clause about threatened matters.
p_60.model_instructions: Consider adding a knowledge qualifier to the entire representation for consistency: 'To Seller's knowledge, Seller is not a party to any action, litigation, suit, arbitration, unsatisfied order or judgment, governmental investigation or pending proceeding that would affect Seller's ability to execute, deliver and perform all of its obligations under this Agreement, and no such matter is threatened against the Property or Seller.' Alternatively, verify Seller has conducted appropriate diligence to confirm this representation is accurate.
p_60.problematic_text: Seller is not a party to any action, litigation, suit, arbitration, unsatisfied order or judgment, governmental investigation or pending proceeding
p_60.title: Unqualified Pending Actions Representation
p_60.user_recommendation: Confirm Seller has verified no unknown governmental investigations exist.

p_61.description: The representation is limited to 'written notification' received by Seller. This is appropriately protective for Seller, but ensure this standard is consistent and that Buyer cannot argue verbal notices or other forms of communication trigger liability. The phrase 'which violation has not been cured' provides good protection but could be clearer about who determines if a cure is sufficient.
p_61.model_instructions: This clause is generally protective of Seller's interests. The limitation to 'written notification' is market-standard and appropriate. No changes recommended, but flag for Seller to confirm no written notices have been received and retained in files. The representation is appropriately limited in scope.
p_61.problematic_text: Seller has not received any written notification
p_61.title: Violation Representation Limited to Written Notices
p_61.user_recommendation: This is appropriately protective language for Seller - no change needed.

p_62.description: The phrase 'threatened against Seller in writing' is somewhat awkward - condemnation proceedings are typically threatened against property, not the property owner. This could create ambiguity about what constitutes adequate disclosure. Additionally, the knowledge qualifier only applies to threatened proceedings, not pending proceedings.
p_62.model_instructions: Consider clarifying the language to read: 'No condemnation proceedings relating to the Property or its access to or from public streets or utilities are pending, and, to Seller's knowledge, no such proceedings have been threatened in writing.' This removes the awkward 'against Seller' language and makes clear the knowledge qualifier applies to threats while the absolute statement applies to actual pending proceedings.
p_62.problematic_text: have been threatened against Seller in writing
p_62.title: Condemnation Threatened 'Against Seller' Language
p_62.user_recommendation: Clarify that this covers threats regarding the Property received by Seller.

p_63.description: The environmental representation is appropriately limited to 'written notice from any Governmental Entity or neighboring property owner,' which protects Seller from liability for unknown conditions or verbal communications. This is favorable to Seller but Buyer may push back seeking broader representations.
p_63.model_instructions: This representation is appropriately narrow from Seller's perspective. Maintain the 'written notice' qualifier and the limitation to Governmental Entities and neighboring property owners. Resist any Buyer requests to expand this to include 'actual knowledge,' remove the written notice requirement, or add representations about the actual condition of the Property. If Buyer requests broader environmental representations, counter by emphasizing the as-is nature of the transaction and Buyer's due diligence rights.
p_63.problematic_text: Seller has received no written notice from any Governmental Entity or neighboring property owner
p_63.title: Written Notice Limitation Appropriately Limits Seller Exposure
p_63.user_recommendation: Maintain this language; resist Buyer attempts to expand scope.

p_63.description: The definition of 'Environmental Laws' is very broad, encompassing 'all federal, state and local laws, rules, statutes, directives, binding written interpretations, binding written policies, ordinances and regulations.' This broad scope could theoretically expand what constitutes a violation that Seller must disclose, though the written notice requirement mitigates this risk.
p_63.model_instructions: If the opportunity arises to renegotiate, consider narrowing the Environmental Laws definition to specifically enumerated statutes (CERCLA, RCRA, Clean Water Act, Clean Air Act, and state equivalents) rather than this catch-all approach. The current broad language could potentially capture minor regulatory guidance that creates technical violations. However, given the written notice limitation in the main representation, this is a lower priority modification.
p_63.problematic_text: all federal, state and local laws, rules, statutes, directives, binding written interpretations, binding written policies, ordinances and regulations relating to the environment
p_63.title: Broad Environmental Laws Definition May Expand Liability
p_63.user_recommendation: Consider narrowing to principal statutes only if renegotiating.

p_64.description: This representation only confirms that Seller has provided access to Licenses and Permits 'to the extent in Seller's possession or control.' This is favorable to Seller as it does not warrant completeness, validity, or transferability of such licenses. Seller has no liability for licenses that exist but are not in Seller's possession.
p_64.model_instructions: This representation is appropriately limited from Seller's perspective. Maintain the qualifier 'to the extent in Seller's possession or control.' Resist any Buyer requests to: (1) warrant that all necessary licenses and permits have been obtained; (2) warrant that such licenses are valid, current, or transferable; (3) warrant that the Property is in compliance with all licensing requirements; or (4) remove the possession/control limitation. The current formulation is strictly a disclosure obligation, not a compliance warranty.
p_64.problematic_text: to the extent in Seller's possession or control
p_64.title: Licenses Representation Appropriately Limited to Possession
p_64.user_recommendation: Maintain this limited scope; favorable to Seller.

p_65.description: This representation that Seller is not a foreign person under IRC Section 1445 is standard and required for FIRPTA compliance. It is necessary to avoid withholding requirements at closing. Seller will be required to deliver a FIRPTA affidavit at closing per Section 11.4.5.
p_65.model_instructions: This is a standard and necessary FIRPTA representation. No modification is recommended. However, ensure that Seller can accurately make this representation before execution. If Seller is a disregarded entity, confirm that the tax owner is not a foreign person. This representation should be consistent with the FIRPTA affidavit required under Section 11.4.5.
p_65.problematic_text: Seller is not a foreign person under Section 1445 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986
p_65.title: FIRPTA Representation is Standard and Necessary
p_65.user_recommendation: Standard provision; confirm accuracy before signing.

p_66.description: This representation that no person has any right of first offer or right of first refusal is absolute and unqualified. Unlike other representations limited to Seller's knowledge or receipt of written notice, this is a flat representation. If any such right exists in recorded documents or agreements that Seller's deal team is unaware of, Seller could be in breach despite good faith.
p_66.model_instructions: Consider modifying this representation to add a knowledge qualifier consistent with other representations in this Agreement. Suggested revision: 'To Seller's Knowledge, no person has any right of first offer or right of first refusal to purchase the Property, or any portion thereof, arising through Seller.' Alternatively, limit the representation to rights 'created by Seller or contained in the Leases' to exclude any rights that may have been created by prior owners and were not disclosed to Seller. Review all Leases for ROFO/ROFR provisions before confirming this representation.
p_66.problematic_text: No person has any right of first offer or right of first refusal to purchase the Property, or any portion thereof, arising through Seller
p_66.title: Unqualified ROFO/ROFR Representation Lacks Knowledge Qualifier

p_67.description: This representation speaks 'As of the Closing Date' rather than as of the Effective Date, meaning Seller is making a forward-looking representation about a future state of affairs. If an unexpected party claims possession rights before closing (e.g., adverse possession claim, holdover tenant dispute), Seller could be in breach through no fault of its own. This representation survives closing per Section 5.4 and creates ongoing exposure.
p_67.model_instructions: This representation should be modified to limit Seller's risk for circumstances beyond Seller's control. Consider the following revision: 'As of the Closing Date, to Seller's Knowledge, there shall be no tenants with a right to possession of any portion of the Property, except for the Tenants under the Leases described on Exhibit J attached hereto, tenants under leases approved by Buyer under Section 7.3, or parties whose claims to possession arise after the Effective Date through no act or omission of Seller.' This protects Seller from breach due to third-party claims that materialize between signing and closing. Review Section 5.3 regarding reaffirmation of representations at closing.
p_67.problematic_text: As of the Closing Date, there shall be no tenants with a right to possession of any portion of the Property, except for the Tenants under the Leases
p_67.title: Closing Date Representation Creates Future Compliance Risk
p_67.user_recommendation: Add qualifier for tenants 'to Seller's Knowledge' or claims arising after Effective Date.

p_67.description: This representation incorporates Exhibit J (the lease schedule) by reference. Any inaccuracies in Exhibit J could cause a breach of this representation. Seller should verify that Exhibit J is complete and accurate before execution.
p_67.model_instructions: Before execution, conduct a thorough review to ensure Exhibit J accurately lists all current tenants and occupants of the Property. This should include a review of: (1) all executed leases; (2) any license agreements granting occupancy rights; (3) any month-to-month tenancies; (4) any subleases of which Seller is aware; and (5) any pending lease negotiations that may result in executed leases before closing. Also verify consistency between this representation and Section 5.1.15 regarding Leases.
p_67.problematic_text: except for the Tenants under the Leases described on Exhibit J attached hereto
p_67.title: Representation Depends on Accuracy of Exhibit J
p_67.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit J is complete and accurate before signing.

p_68.description: The representation that 'All of the Leases are in full force and effect' is made without any knowledge qualifier. This is an absolute statement that could expose Seller to liability even for matters Seller could not reasonably know about, such as undisclosed tenant claims or technical defaults unknown to Seller's property management.
p_68.model_instructions: Modify the sentence to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, all of the Leases are in full force and effect.' This limits Seller's exposure to matters actually known to Seller and is consistent with the knowledge qualifier already applied to tenant defaults in the same paragraph.
p_68.problematic_text: All of the Leases are in full force and effect.
p_68.title: Absolute Representation on Lease Status
p_68.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

p_68.description: The statement 'There are no uncured landlord defaults or breaches' lacks any knowledge qualifier, unlike the tenant defaults representation in the same sentence. This asymmetry creates strict liability for Seller regarding any landlord default, even technical or unknown defaults that property management may not have disclosed to Seller.
p_68.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, there are no uncured landlord defaults or breaches, or uncured tenant defaults or breaches, under the Leases.' This applies the knowledge qualifier uniformly to both landlord and tenant defaults.
p_68.problematic_text: There are no uncured landlord defaults or breaches
p_68.title: Absolute No Landlord Defaults Representation
p_68.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier for consistency.

p_68.description: The representation that rent rolls 'are true, correct and complete in all material respects as of the date thereof' applies to all rent rolls provided, potentially including preliminary or outdated versions. This could create liability for early-stage documents that were superseded by updated rent rolls closer to closing.
p_68.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'The rent roll to be provided pursuant to Section 7.4 below shall be true, correct and complete in all material respects as of the date thereof and identify all Leases in effect as of such date.' This limits the representation to the final, updated rent roll rather than all interim versions.
p_68.problematic_text: The rent rolls provided to Buyer pursuant to this Agreement (including the rent roll(s) to be provided pursuant to Section 7.4 below) are true, correct and complete in all material respects as of the date thereof
p_68.title: Rent Roll Accuracy Without Time Limitation
p_68.user_recommendation: Limit representation to the final rent roll delivered at closing.

p_68.description: The absolute representation that there are no other 'licenses, or other agreements to occupy or use' the Property beyond the Leases lacks a knowledge qualifier. This could expose Seller to liability for informal arrangements made by property managers or historic agreements that may have been overlooked.
p_68.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, there are no leases of space in the Property, licenses, or other agreements to occupy or use all or any portion of the Property, which will be in force after the Closing other than the Leases.' Alternatively, add: 'other than as disclosed in the Due Diligence Materials.'
p_68.problematic_text: There are no leases of space in the Property, licenses, or other agreements to occupy or use all or any portion of the Property, which will be in force after the Closing other than the Leases.
p_68.title: No Occupancy Agreements Beyond Leases
p_68.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier or limit to Seller's records.

p_69.description: The representation that Seller is not party to any lease brokerage agreements except those on Exhibit M is stated absolutely without a knowledge qualifier. Seller could be exposed to liability for old or forgotten commission agreements, especially if the Property was previously owned by others or managed by third parties.
p_69.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Except as disclosed in Exhibit M attached hereto ("Commission Agreements"), to Seller's knowledge, Seller is not a party to any lease brokerage agreements, leasing commission agreements or other agreements providing for payments of any amounts for leasing activities or procuring tenants with respect to the Property or any portion or portions thereof...'
p_69.problematic_text: Except as disclosed in Exhibit M attached hereto ("Commission Agreements"), Seller is not a party to any lease brokerage agreements, leasing commission agreements or other agreements providing for payments of any amounts for leasing activities or procuring tenants with respect to the Property
p_69.title: Absolute No Brokerage Agreements Representation
p_69.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

p_69.description: The language that commissions 'have been or shall be paid in full' creates an ongoing obligation through closing. Combined with Section 7.3, this could create ambiguity about which commissions Seller remains responsible for if new leasing activity occurs between signing and closing.
p_69.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'all leasing commissions and brokerage fees accrued or due and payable under the Commission Agreements with respect to the Property as of the Effective Date have been paid in full or will be paid by Seller at or prior to Closing, subject to the provisions of Section 7.3.' This creates clarity about the temporal scope and cross-references the leasing cost allocation provisions.
p_69.problematic_text: all leasing commissions and brokerage fees accrued or due and payable under the Commission Agreements with respect to the Property as of the date hereof have been or shall be paid in full
p_69.title: Commission Payment Obligation Through Closing
p_69.user_recommendation: Clarify that this applies only to commissions accrued as of Agreement date.

p_70.description: The representation that there are no contracts binding on Buyer after Closing except Leases, Permitted Exceptions, and Assumed Contracts is stated absolutely without a knowledge qualifier. Seller could face liability for contracts entered into by property managers, service providers with auto-renewal provisions, or historic agreements not in Seller's active files.
p_70.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, there are no contracts or other agreements with respect to the Property which will be binding on Buyer after the Closing other than the Leases, the Permitted Exceptions, and the Assumed Contracts.' This is consistent with the knowledge qualifier applied to defaults in the second sentence.
p_70.problematic_text: There are no contracts or other agreements with respect to the Property which will be binding on Buyer after the Closing other than the Leases, the Permitted Exceptions, and the Assumed Contracts.
p_70.title: Absolute No Binding Contracts Representation
p_70.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

p_71.description: The absolute representation that 'Seller has no employees' and that there are no employment-related agreements affecting the Property is made without any knowledge qualifier. This creates strict liability if any employment arrangements exist through property management companies, building engineers, or other personnel who might be deemed employees under various legal tests.
p_71.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Seller has no employees at the Property, and to Seller's knowledge, there are no employment agreements, union agreements, benefit agreements, pension plans, or collective bargaining agreements at or otherwise affecting the Property to which Seller is bound which will survive the Closing or for which Buyer will be responsible for or have any obligation or other liability for after the Closing. Personnel providing services at the Property are employed by the property manager or other third-party contractors.'
p_71.problematic_text: Seller has no employees, and there are no employment agreements, union agreements, benefit agreements, pension plans, or collective bargaining agreements at or otherwise affecting the Property to which Seller is bound
p_71.title: Absolute No Employees Representation
p_71.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and carve-out for property management arrangements.

p_72.description: The representation that 'the Due Diligence Materials are true and correct in all material respects' is extraordinarily broad. Due Diligence Materials typically include third-party reports, tenant-provided information, historical records, and other documents over which Seller has no control. This creates potential liability for inaccuracies in documents Seller did not prepare.
p_72.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, the Due Diligence Materials prepared by Seller or its agents are true and correct in all material respects. Seller makes no representation or warranty regarding the accuracy or completeness of third-party reports, tenant-provided information, or other documents not prepared by Seller that are included in the Due Diligence Materials.'
p_72.problematic_text: To Seller's knowledge, the Due Diligence Materials are true and correct in all material respects and do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading.
p_72.title: Broad Due Diligence Materials Accuracy Representation
p_72.user_recommendation: Limit representation to documents prepared by Seller only.

p_72.description: The representation that Due Diligence Materials 'do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading' imposes a securities-law-type disclosure standard that is extremely broad for real estate transactions. This could be interpreted as requiring disclosure of every potentially material fact.
p_72.model_instructions: Delete the phrase 'and do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading' entirely. The no fraudulent concealment language in the first sentence already addresses intentional withholding, which is appropriate. The broader no-omissions language creates an unmanageable disclosure standard.
p_72.problematic_text: do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading
p_72.title: No Omissions Representation Creates Expansive Duty
p_72.user_recommendation: Delete or narrow the no-omissions language.

p_75.description: The knowledge definition is favorable to Seller as it limits knowledge to only two named individuals (Robert Martinez and Jennifer Williams) with no duty of inquiry and no imputation of knowledge. This is a protective provision for Seller. However, Seller should verify that these are indeed the correct individuals with primary responsibility for property matters, as naming individuals who lack actual knowledge could create issues if a Buyer later claims the wrong people were named.
p_75.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller. No changes needed unless client wishes to add additional knowledge parties or confirm the named individuals are appropriate. If modifying, ensure any additions maintain the 'no duty of inquiry' and 'no imputation' protections.
p_75.problematic_text: without duty of inquiry or imputation of knowledge
p_75.title: Knowledge Definition Appropriately Limited
p_75.user_recommendation: Confirm named individuals are correct and have property knowledge.

p_77.description: This provision creates an affirmative obligation on Seller to give notice to Buyer of any change in condition or any changed condition that would make representations inaccurate. This duty to disclose could be interpreted broadly and creates ongoing monitoring obligations for Seller between signing and closing. Failure to provide such notice could be characterized as a default or breach.
p_77.model_instructions: Revise the notice obligation to apply only to 'material' changes: 'Unless Seller gives notice to Buyer of any material change in the condition of the Property subsequent to the Effective Date or of any other material changed condition that would make any of the representations or warranties in Section 5.1 materially inaccurate, incomplete or misleading'. This prevents triggering notice obligations for immaterial or de minimis changes.
p_77.problematic_text: Unless Seller gives notice to Buyer of any change in the condition of the Property subsequent to the Effective Date or of any other changed condition that would make any of the representations or warranties in Section 5.1 inaccurate, incomplete or misleading
p_77.title: Affirmative Duty to Disclose Changes
p_77.user_recommendation: Consider adding 'material' qualifier to notice obligation.

p_77.description: This provision grants Buyer a termination right with full deposit return if any representation becomes inaccurate, even for changes outside Seller's control. This is a significant risk as it essentially creates a broad walk-away right for Buyer based on changed circumstances, market conditions, or third-party actions that affect representation accuracy. The 5-day window is short, but the right itself is very broad.
p_77.model_instructions: Revise to limit Buyer's termination right: 'In the event any of the foregoing Seller's representations and warranties become materially inaccurate due to circumstances within Seller's reasonable control, then Buyer may elect to either (i) terminate this Agreement and receive a full return of the Earnest Money Deposit by giving Seller written notice of such termination within 5 Business Days after Buyer received notice of such material inaccuracy (with the Closing Date extended to accommodate such 5 Business Days period), or (ii) proceed with the Closing with knowledge and acceptance of such facts. For changes outside Seller's control that render representations inaccurate, Buyer's sole remedy shall be to proceed to Closing or terminate without the return of the Earnest Money Deposit.'
p_77.problematic_text: Buyer may elect to either (i) to terminate this Agreement and receive a full return of the Earnest Money Deposit by giving Seller written notice of such termination within 5 Business Days after Buyer received or delivered notice of such inaccuracy
p_77.title: Buyer Termination Right for Rep Changes
p_77.user_recommendation: Limit termination right to material changes within Seller's control.

p_77.description: The carve-out providing Buyer 'all rights and remedies for default' when changes are 'within Seller's control' is vague and could be interpreted broadly. What constitutes 'within Seller's control' is subjective and could lead to disputes. Additionally, granting 'all rights and remedies' could be interpreted to include specific performance or consequential damages beyond the caps in Section 5.4.
p_77.model_instructions: Revise to clarify the scope: 'if such Seller's representations and warranties are no longer accurate due to Seller's intentional or grossly negligent acts (as opposed to market conditions, tenant actions, governmental actions, or other third-party conduct), then, subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 and Section 13.1 below, Buyer shall have available to it the remedies set forth in Section 13.1 for Seller default.' This ties the remedy to the default provision and clarifies what 'control' means.
p_77.problematic_text: if such Seller's representations and warranties are no longer accurate due to reasons or causes within Seller's control, then, subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 below, Buyer shall have available to it all of the rights and remedies for default and Seller's breach
p_77.title: Full Remedies for 'Within Control' Changes
p_77.user_recommendation: Define 'within Seller's control' and clarify remedy limitations apply.

p_78.description: The 12-month survival period for representations and warranties is relatively standard and favorable to Seller. Many buyers push for 18-24 months. This provision adequately protects Seller's interest in finality.
p_78.model_instructions: No changes needed. This is a seller-favorable provision with a reasonable survival period.
p_78.problematic_text: shall survive for a period of 12 months from the Closing Date
p_78.title: 12-Month Survival Period is Reasonable
p_78.user_recommendation: Provision is favorable; no changes recommended.

p_78.description: The $25,000 deductible/threshold and the cap of greater of $1,000,000 or 5% of Purchase Price are reasonable protections for Seller. These provisions effectively limit Seller's exposure to representation breaches.
p_78.model_instructions: No changes required. If client wishes to further limit exposure, consider reducing the cap to the lesser of $1,000,000 or 3% of Purchase Price, though this may face buyer resistance.
p_78.problematic_text: under no circumstances shall Seller be liable to Buyer on account of any breach of any representation or warranty in the aggregate in excess of the amount equal to the greater of (i) $1,000,000 and (ii) 5% of the Purchase Price
p_78.title: Liability Cap Structure is Favorable
p_78.user_recommendation: Provision is favorable; consider if cap should be lower.

p_78.description: Both the deductible and the liability cap expressly exclude attorneys' fees. This means Seller could face uncapped liability for attorneys' fees in connection with representation breach claims, which could significantly exceed the stated cap in contentious litigation.
p_78.model_instructions: Remove the attorneys' fees exclusions to ensure the cap applies comprehensively: '(a) Buyer shall not make a claim against Seller for damages for breach or default of any representation or warranty, unless the amount of such claim is reasonably anticipated to exceed $25,000; and (b) under no circumstances shall Seller be liable to Buyer on account of any breach of any representation or warranty in the aggregate in excess of the amount equal to the greater of (i) $1,000,000 and (ii) 5% of the Purchase Price, inclusive of all attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses.'
p_78.title: Attorney Fees Excluded from Cap
p_78.user_recommendation: Include attorneys' fees within the liability cap.

p_79.description: Section 6 introduces Buyer's representations but does not include parallel limitations to those protecting Seller in Sections 5.3 and 5.4 (such as survival periods, deductibles, and caps). This creates an asymmetry where Seller's claims against Buyer for representation breaches may be unlimited while Buyer's claims against Seller are capped.
p_79.model_instructions: Add a new subsection after Section 6.6 (or at the end of Buyer's representations): '6.7 Survival and Limitations. Buyer's representations and warranties shall survive Closing without limitation as to time or amount. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 shall not apply to any breach by Buyer of its representations and warranties hereunder.' Alternatively, if symmetry is preferred, reference Section 5.4 mutually.
p_79.problematic_text: 6.	BUYER'S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES.  Buyer represents and warrants to Seller, as of the Effective Date and as of Closing, the following:
p_79.title: Buyer Reps Lack Parallel Limitations
p_79.user_recommendation: Confirm Buyer's reps have unlimited survival or add parallel caps.

p_8.description: The Closing Date is subject to extensions under at least eight different sections (4.4, 5.3, 7.2, 11.2.1, 11.2.2, 11.8, 13.1, and 13.2). This creates significant uncertainty for Seller regarding when closing will actually occur and extends Seller's exposure period. Multiple extension mechanisms favor Buyer by allowing delays while Seller remains bound. Seller cannot market the property to other buyers during extended periods and bears ongoing carrying costs.
p_8.model_instructions: Add a limitation on cumulative extensions: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing extension rights, in no event shall the Closing Date be extended more than sixty (60) days beyond April 30, 2026, unless Seller agrees in writing. If Closing has not occurred by such outside date, Seller may terminate this Agreement upon written notice to Buyer and retain the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages.' Review each referenced section to ensure Seller has appropriate protections and consider whether all extension rights are necessary.
p_8.problematic_text: The Closing Date is subject to possible extensions as provided in Sections 4.4, 5.3, 7.2, 11.2.1, 11.2.2, 11.8, 13.1 and 13.2 below
p_8.title: Excessive Closing Date Extension Provisions
p_8.user_recommendation: Cap total extensions and add Seller termination right after maximum period.

p_8.description: The provision allows for earlier closing only if agreed by both parties. Seller has no unilateral right to accelerate closing even if Buyer's conditions are satisfied early. This limits Seller's flexibility to close quickly if circumstances warrant (e.g., favorable market conditions, Seller's business needs).
p_8.model_instructions: Consider adding language allowing Seller to accelerate closing with adequate notice: 'Seller may accelerate the Closing Date to any date not less than ten (10) Business Days after written notice to Buyer, provided all conditions to Buyer's obligation to close have been satisfied or waived.' Alternatively, leave as-is if Seller prefers the certainty of the fixed date.
p_8.problematic_text: or such earlier date as may be agreed to by Buyer and Seller in writing
p_8.title: No Seller Right to Accelerate Closing
p_8.user_recommendation: Consider adding Seller acceleration right with reasonable notice.

p_80.description: Buyer represents it is a Delaware LLC in good standing, but there is no requirement that Buyer qualify to do business in the state where the Property is located (Washington, based on context). If Buyer is not qualified in Washington, this could create enforcement issues or complications at closing.
p_80.model_instructions: Revise to include foreign qualification: 'Buyer is a limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of Delaware and is qualified to conduct business in the State of Washington (or will be so qualified prior to Closing).'
p_80.problematic_text: Buyer is a limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of Delaware
p_80.title: Buyer Delaware LLC Status
p_80.user_recommendation: Add requirement for Buyer to be qualified in Property state.

p_81.description: This provision explicitly acknowledges that Buyer may not yet have internal authorization to proceed to Closing at the time of contract execution. While Buyer represents it will obtain such authorization before issuing the Buyer Approval Notice, this creates significant risk for Seller. If Buyer fails to obtain internal approvals during due diligence, Buyer can simply decline to issue the Buyer Approval Notice and terminate the agreement, effectively using the due diligence period as a free option period while Seller's property is tied up. This is a one-sided arrangement that favors Buyer.
p_81.model_instructions: Revise to require Buyer to have obtained all necessary internal authorizations prior to execution of this Agreement, or alternatively, add a specific shorter deadline (e.g., 10 Business Days) by which Buyer must confirm receipt of all internal authorizations, independent of the Due Diligence Period. Consider adding that failure to obtain such approvals by the specified date constitutes a Buyer default entitling Seller to the Earnest Money Deposit.
p_81.problematic_text: although Buyer is authorized to enter into this Agreement, Buyer may only be authorized to issue the Buyer Approval Notice and proceed to Closing if and when it receives additional internal authorizations during the Due Diligence Period
p_81.title: Buyer May Lack Closing Authorization
p_81.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to confirm full authorization at signing or provide shorter approval period.

p_81.description: The phrase 'additional internal authorizations' is undefined and entirely within Buyer's control. Buyer could claim it needs investment committee approval, board approval, partner consent, or any number of internal hurdles that Seller cannot verify or influence. This gives Buyer excessive discretion to terminate during the due diligence period based on purported failure to obtain unspecified internal approvals.
p_81.model_instructions: Add a requirement that Buyer must identify in an exhibit or schedule all specific internal authorizations required to proceed to Closing, including the authorizing body, expected timeline, and criteria for approval. Add language stating that Seller shall have no liability and the Earnest Money Deposit shall be forfeited if Buyer fails to obtain internal approvals that were not disclosed at signing.
p_81.title: Undefined 'Internal Authorizations' Standard
p_81.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to identify all required internal approvals in the Agreement.

p_82.description: This section references 'Section 6.1.2 above' for an exception to the consent representation, but the Buyer's Representations section appears to start at 6.1 (Status) without a subsection 6.1.2. This creates ambiguity about what consents may actually be required and could allow Buyer to claim undisclosed consent requirements exist as an exception.
p_82.model_instructions: Confirm whether Section 6.1.2 exists in the final document. If not, either (a) delete the phrase 'Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above' so that Buyer's representation is unqualified, or (b) insert the correct section reference. If the reference relates to Buyer's authorization contingency in Section 6.2, consider whether this exception undermines the consent representation entirely.
p_82.problematic_text: Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above
p_82.title: Reference to Non-Existent Section 6.1.2
p_82.user_recommendation: Verify correct cross-reference or delete the exception entirely.

p_82.description: The reference to Section 6.1.2 suggests there may be consent requirements that Buyer has not yet obtained. Combined with the internal authorization language in Section 6.2, this could mean Buyer has multiple outs from the transaction. Seller should understand exactly what consents remain outstanding.
p_82.model_instructions: Add a requirement that Buyer must disclose in writing all consents, waivers, approvals or authorizations that have not yet been obtained, including from any lenders, investors, partners, or internal governance bodies, and the expected timeline for obtaining each.
p_82.problematic_text: Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above
p_82.title: Potential Undisclosed Consent Requirements
p_82.user_recommendation: Request Buyer to disclose all outstanding consent requirements.

p_84.description: The OFAC representation extends to 'any of their respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners' which may include passive investors or fund participants that Buyer cannot fully verify. While this representation is standard, Buyer may resist if it has complex ownership structures. This is generally favorable to Seller as drafted.
p_84.model_instructions: This provision is generally favorable to Seller. If Buyer requests a knowledge qualifier, resist or limit any qualifier to only those equity holders owning more than a specified threshold (e.g., 10% or 25%). Ensure that the representation extends to the full ownership chain to the extent reasonably knowable by Buyer.
p_84.problematic_text: nor any of their respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners
p_84.title: Broad OFAC Representation Covers Unknown Parties
p_84.user_recommendation: Confirm representation is acceptable; consider adding knowledge qualifier resistance.

p_87.description: Seller must obtain Conforming Tenant Estoppels covering 80% of leased square footage plus ALL Major Tenants as a condition to Buyer's obligation to close. This is a high threshold that gives Buyer significant leverage and potential exit opportunities if any Major Tenant fails to return an estoppel or returns one with any inconsistency. Seller has no control over tenant cooperation, yet bears the risk of transaction failure.
p_87.model_instructions: Revise to reduce the estoppel threshold from 80% to 70% of leased square footage. Add language permitting Seller to deliver a Seller-executed estoppel certificate in lieu of a tenant-executed certificate for non-Major Tenants if the tenant fails to respond, with Seller representing the accuracy of information therein. Consider adding a materiality threshold for what constitutes a 'Nonconforming' estoppel.
p_87.problematic_text: Receipt of Conforming Tenant Estoppels (as defined below) from the Major Tenants (plus a sufficient number of other Tenants under Leases so that Buyer receives Conforming Tenant Estoppels for Leases covering at least 80% of the currently leased square footage
p_87.title: High Estoppel Threshold Burden
p_87.user_recommendation: Reduce threshold to 70% and allow Seller-executed estoppels for non-Major Tenants.

p_87.description: Buyer has broad termination rights if Seller cannot cure estoppel inconsistencies. Combined with the low threshold for what constitutes a 'Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel' (any material matter inconsistent with Due Diligence Materials OR Seller's representations), this gives Buyer substantial ability to exit the transaction late in the process without penalty if market conditions change.
p_87.model_instructions: Modify the definition of Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel to require that the inconsistency be 'materially adverse to Buyer's interest in the Property' and involve either (a) a rent reduction exceeding $X annually, (b) an unscheduled termination right, or (c) landlord obligations exceeding $X. Add language that minor or immaterial inconsistencies shall not give rise to termination rights and Buyer must accept such estoppels as Conforming.
p_87.problematic_text: Buyer, as its sole remedy therefor, may elect to either: (i) postpone Closing one time for up to 14 days to allow Seller to attempt to accomplish such cure, (ii) terminate this Agreement, in which event the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer
p_87.title: Buyer Termination Right for Estoppel Issues
p_87.user_recommendation: Add materiality threshold and limit termination to issues exceeding defined dollar thresholds.

p_87.description: While Buyer can terminate for Nonconforming Estoppels, if Buyer elects to close despite the inconsistencies, there is no purchase price reduction. This seems protective of Seller but actually creates perverse incentives - Buyer is more likely to terminate rather than negotiate a resolution because closing means accepting the issue at full price.
p_87.model_instructions: Add an option (iv) that allows Buyer and Seller to negotiate in good faith a purchase price reduction reflecting the economic impact of the inconsistent matter, with the adjustment amount to be mutually agreed or, if not agreed within 5 Business Days, either party may elect termination or proceed at the original Purchase Price.
p_87.problematic_text: close the transaction regardless of the inconsistent matter(s) disclosed in the Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel(s) (in which case they shall be treated as Conforming Tenant Estoppel(s)) without a reduction in the Purchase Price
p_87.title: No Price Reduction for Estoppel Issues
p_87.user_recommendation: Consider allowing negotiated price adjustment as alternative to termination.
