Modify to read: 'If Seller does not elect to cure the New Title Objection, then Buyer's sole options shall be either (a) to accept the disapproved New Title Objection as a Permitted Exception, or (b) if such New Title Objection would have a material adverse effect on Buyer's intended use or the value of the Property (a reduction in value of more than $500,000), by written notice to Seller within 5 Business Days of Seller's election of non-removal, to terminate this Agreement, in which case the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer within 2 Business Days after termination. For any New Title Objection that does not meet the foregoing materiality threshold, Buyer's sole option shall be clause (a) above.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Seller does not elect to cure the New Title Objection, then Buyer's sole options shall be either (a) to accept the disapproved New Title Objection as a Permitted Exception, or (b) by written notice to Seller within 5 Business Days of Seller's election of non-removal, to terminate this Agreement, in which case the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer within 2 Business Days after termination.
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Termination Right for New Title Exceptions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit termination right to material new exceptions only.

risk_inventory.description: The provision states that 'the Closing Date shall be extended to accommodate the time periods established in this Section 4.4.' This gives Buyer an automatic extension of the Closing Date whenever new title exceptions arise, with no cap on the length of extension. This could delay closing significantly and is entirely within Buyer's control since Buyer decides whether to object to new exceptions.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the closing extension provision to add a cap: 'To the extent necessary, the Closing Date shall be extended to accommodate the time periods established in this Section 4.4; provided, however, that in no event shall such extension exceed fifteen (15) Business Days in the aggregate for all New Title Objections arising under this Section 4.4.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To the extent necessary, the Closing Date shall be extended to accommodate the time periods established in this Section 4.4.
risk_inventory.title: Automatic Closing Date Extension for New Exceptions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cap the automatic closing extension at 15 Business Days total.

risk_inventory.description: If Buyer fails to act within 5 Business Days of receipt of Seller's election not to remove a New Title Objection, Buyer is deemed to have accepted the exception as a Permitted Exception. This is favorable to Seller as it prevents Buyer from holding the transaction hostage through inaction.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No changes recommended. This deemed acceptance provision protects Seller by ensuring that Buyer's inaction results in acceptance of the exception rather than continued uncertainty.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's failure to act within 5 Business Days of receipt of Seller's election not to remove a New Title Objection shall be deemed an election under clause (a) to accept the disapproved New Title Objection as a Permitted Exception.
risk_inventory.title: Deemed Acceptance on Buyer Inaction - Favorable to Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: No changes recommended - this provision favors Seller.

risk_inventory.description: Seller is obligated to execute 'such affidavits and other documents as the Title Company customarily or reasonably requires to issue extended coverage.' This is an open-ended obligation that allows the Title Company to require additional documents at closing. While the 'customarily or reasonably' qualifier provides some protection, Title Companies sometimes require extensive owner affidavits with representations that could expose Seller to liability.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to add Seller approval right: 'Seller shall execute and deliver to the Title Company on or before Closing such affidavits and other documents as the Title Company customarily or reasonably requires to issue extended coverage, provided that such affidavits and documents shall be in form and substance reasonably acceptable to Seller and shall not require Seller to make any representations beyond those expressly set forth in this Agreement or expand Seller's liability beyond the limitations set forth herein ("Owner's Title Affidavit").'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall execute and deliver to the Title Company on or before Closing such affidavits and other documents as the Title Company customarily or reasonably requires to issue extended coverage
risk_inventory.title: Seller Must Execute 'Customarily Required' Documents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add that required documents must be in form reasonably acceptable to Seller.

risk_inventory.description: The representations are made both 'as of the Effective Date and as of Closing,' which means Seller must ensure all representations remain accurate at Closing, even if circumstances change due to events beyond Seller's control during the contract period. This creates exposure for Seller if market conditions, tenant situations, or third-party actions cause a representation to become inaccurate between signing and closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the introductory language to state that representations are made as of the Effective Date only, with a limited bring-down certificate at Closing confirming that Seller has no actual knowledge of any material breach. Alternatively, add language stating that representations made as of Closing shall be subject to any changes disclosed to Buyer in writing prior to Closing, which changes shall not constitute a breach if Buyer proceeds to Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as of the Effective Date and as of Closing
risk_inventory.title: Representations Made at Two Time Points
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit representations to Effective Date only with bring-down to Seller's knowledge at Closing.

risk_inventory.description: This representation is stated in absolute terms without any knowledge qualifier. While status representations are typically factual, if there is any administrative issue with the entity's good standing that Seller is unaware of (e.g., a filing error by the Secretary of State), Seller could be in technical breach.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding a proviso that allows Seller a reasonable cure period (e.g., 10 business days) to remedy any administrative deficiencies in its good standing status that may be identified prior to Closing, provided such deficiencies do not materially impact Seller's ability to convey the Property.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller is a Delaware limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing
risk_inventory.title: Absolute Status Representation Without Qualification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add ability to cure administrative issues discovered before Closing.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that 'this Agreement constitutes the legal, valid and binding obligation of Seller' is stated broadly. While standard, combined with the dual timing in p_53, this creates ongoing exposure. Additionally, the phrase 'have been or will be duly authorized' is forward-looking and could create issues if internal approvals are delayed.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to state that authorization 'has been' (not 'will be') duly obtained as of execution, ensuring Seller has completed all necessary internal approvals before signing. Confirm the existing carve-outs for 'equitable principles and principles governing creditors' rights generally' are adequate, and consider adding specific carve-outs for applicable bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, moratorium, and similar laws affecting creditors' rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: have been or will be duly authorized by all necessary action on the part of Seller and this Agreement constitutes the legal, valid and binding obligation of Seller
risk_inventory.title: Binding Obligation Representation Potentially Overreaching
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm authorization is complete at signing; add standard enforceability exceptions.

risk_inventory.description: This representation states absolutely that no consent is required from any 'person or entity' for Seller to perform. This is extremely broad and could include consents that are unknown to Seller or that arise from third-party agreements. If any consent is later discovered to be required, Seller would be in breach regardless of Seller's knowledge or the materiality of such consent.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to add a knowledge qualifier: 'To Seller's Knowledge, no consent, waiver, approval or authorization is required from any person or entity...' Also add a materiality qualifier: '...that would materially impair Seller's ability to perform its obligations hereunder or consummate the transactions contemplated hereby.' This protects Seller from technical breaches involving minor or unknown consent requirements.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No consent, waiver, approval or authorization is required from any person or entity (that has not already been obtained)
risk_inventory.title: Absolute No-Consent Representation Creates Trap
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and materiality threshold to consent representation.

risk_inventory.description: This representation is extremely broad, covering all judgments, orders, regulations, organizational documents, notes, mortgages, leases, and 'any lease or other material agreement or instrument.' The breadth creates significant exposure if any unknown encumbrance, judgment, or contractual restriction exists. The lack of a knowledge qualifier means Seller warrants against matters it may have no way of knowing about.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a knowledge qualifier at the beginning: 'To Seller's Knowledge, the execution and delivery...' Also consider limiting the scope to 'material' judgments, orders, or violations that would 'materially and adversely affect' the transaction. Additionally, for agreements and instruments, limit to those 'to which Seller is a party and of which Seller has actual knowledge' rather than broad constructive knowledge.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: will not violate any judgment, order, injunction, decree, regulation or ruling of any court or the various state, local and federal governmental agencies having jurisdiction over Seller, the Property or any portion thereof
risk_inventory.title: Sweeping Non-Contravention Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and limit to agreements actually known to Seller.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'any lease or other material agreement or instrument to which Seller is a party' creates exposure related to tenant leases. If any tenant lease contains a consent requirement, right of first refusal, or transfer restriction that Seller overlooked, this representation would be breached. This should be coordinated with the Leases representation in Section 5.1.15.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language that, with respect to tenant leases, Seller's representation is subject to and limited by the specific representations made in Section 5.1.15 regarding Leases. Add a knowledge qualifier or reference to disclosed documents: 'except as may be disclosed in the tenant leases delivered to Buyer pursuant to Section 3.3.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any lease or other material agreement or instrument to which Seller is a party or by which it is bound
risk_inventory.title: Reference to Any Lease Creates Tenant Agreement Exposure
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference to Lease representation; add knowledge qualifier for tenant lease matters.

risk_inventory.description: This representation extends far beyond Seller itself to include all Affiliates, partners, members, shareholders, equity owners, employees, officers, directors, representatives, and agents. Seller cannot reasonably verify OFAC compliance for all these individuals, particularly employees and agents who may number in the dozens or hundreds. This creates potential liability for circumstances entirely outside Seller's knowledge or control.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to narrow the scope of covered persons. Replace the broad language with: 'Neither Seller nor any of its direct members or managers who hold a 10% or greater ownership interest in Seller is, nor will they become, a person or entity...' This limits the representation to parties Seller can actually verify and control.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates, nor any of its respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners, and none of its respective employees, officers, directors, representatives or agents
risk_inventory.title: Overly Broad OFAC Representation Scope
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit representation to Seller and its direct controlling members/managers.

risk_inventory.description: The representation includes forward-looking language ('nor will they become') that commits Seller to a future state it cannot guarantee. OFAC lists are updated regularly, and Seller has no control over whether a person becomes designated after Closing. This creates ongoing exposure beyond Closing for circumstances Seller cannot predict or prevent.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the forward-looking language 'nor will they become' and revise to read: 'Neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates... is, as of the Closing Date, a person or entity with whom United States persons or entities are restricted from doing business...' This limits the representation to a point-in-time statement rather than an ongoing guarantee.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: nor will they become
risk_inventory.title: Future Compliance Guarantee Is Risky
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit the representation to the current state as of Closing only.

risk_inventory.description: Unlike other representations in this agreement (see 5.1.7, 5.1.9, 5.1.10), this OFAC representation is stated as an absolute fact without any knowledge qualifier. Seller is making an unqualified guarantee about the OFAC status of potentially dozens or hundreds of people, which Seller cannot verify with certainty.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add the knowledge qualifier consistent with Section 5.2's definition. Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates, nor any of its respective members or managers, is a person or entity...' This aligns with the knowledge standard used elsewhere in the agreement and limits Seller's exposure to matters it can actually verify.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Neither Seller nor any of its Affiliates, nor any of its respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners, and none of its respective employees, officers, directors, representatives or agents is
risk_inventory.title: No Knowledge Qualifier on OFAC Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'to Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

risk_inventory.description: The bankruptcy representation is stated as absolute fact. While Seller should generally know its own bankruptcy status, the representation could be qualified to align with other representations and provide consistent protection. This is a minor risk as Seller should have actual knowledge of these matters.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is informational only. The current language is market-standard for bankruptcy representations. If desired for consistency, could add: 'To Seller's knowledge, Seller has not...' but this is not strictly necessary as Seller should have actual knowledge of its own bankruptcy status.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller has not
risk_inventory.title: Bankruptcy Representation Lacks Knowledge Qualifier
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding knowledge qualifier for consistency, though risk is low.

risk_inventory.description: The first clause of this representation (regarding actions that would affect Seller's ability to perform) is stated without a knowledge qualifier, making it an absolute representation. While Seller should know of actions it is a party to, the breadth of 'governmental investigation' could catch matters Seller is unaware of. The knowledge qualifier only applies to the second clause about threatened matters.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding a knowledge qualifier to the entire representation for consistency: 'To Seller's knowledge, Seller is not a party to any action, litigation, suit, arbitration, unsatisfied order or judgment, governmental investigation or pending proceeding that would affect Seller's ability to execute, deliver and perform all of its obligations under this Agreement, and no such matter is threatened against the Property or Seller.' Alternatively, verify Seller has conducted appropriate diligence to confirm this representation is accurate.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller is not a party to any action, litigation, suit, arbitration, unsatisfied order or judgment, governmental investigation or pending proceeding
risk_inventory.title: Unqualified Pending Actions Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm Seller has verified no unknown governmental investigations exist.

risk_inventory.description: The representation is limited to 'written notification' received by Seller. This is appropriately protective for Seller, but ensure this standard is consistent and that Buyer cannot argue verbal notices or other forms of communication trigger liability. The phrase 'which violation has not been cured' provides good protection but could be clearer about who determines if a cure is sufficient.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This clause is generally protective of Seller's interests. The limitation to 'written notification' is market-standard and appropriate. No changes recommended, but flag for Seller to confirm no written notices have been received and retained in files. The representation is appropriately limited in scope.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller has not received any written notification
risk_inventory.title: Violation Representation Limited to Written Notices
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: This is appropriately protective language for Seller - no change needed.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'threatened against Seller in writing' is somewhat awkward - condemnation proceedings are typically threatened against property, not the property owner. This could create ambiguity about what constitutes adequate disclosure. Additionally, the knowledge qualifier only applies to threatened proceedings, not pending proceedings.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider clarifying the language to read: 'No condemnation proceedings relating to the Property or its access to or from public streets or utilities are pending, and, to Seller's knowledge, no such proceedings have been threatened in writing.' This removes the awkward 'against Seller' language and makes clear the knowledge qualifier applies to threats while the absolute statement applies to actual pending proceedings.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: have been threatened against Seller in writing
risk_inventory.title: Condemnation Threatened 'Against Seller' Language
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that this covers threats regarding the Property received by Seller.

risk_inventory.description: The environmental representation is appropriately limited to 'written notice from any Governmental Entity or neighboring property owner,' which protects Seller from liability for unknown conditions or verbal communications. This is favorable to Seller but Buyer may push back seeking broader representations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This representation is appropriately narrow from Seller's perspective. Maintain the 'written notice' qualifier and the limitation to Governmental Entities and neighboring property owners. Resist any Buyer requests to expand this to include 'actual knowledge,' remove the written notice requirement, or add representations about the actual condition of the Property. If Buyer requests broader environmental representations, counter by emphasizing the as-is nature of the transaction and Buyer's due diligence rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller has received no written notice from any Governmental Entity or neighboring property owner
risk_inventory.title: Written Notice Limitation Appropriately Limits Seller Exposure
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Maintain this language; resist Buyer attempts to expand scope.

risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Environmental Laws' is very broad, encompassing 'all federal, state and local laws, rules, statutes, directives, binding written interpretations, binding written policies, ordinances and regulations.' This broad scope could theoretically expand what constitutes a violation that Seller must disclose, though the written notice requirement mitigates this risk.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: If the opportunity arises to renegotiate, consider narrowing the Environmental Laws definition to specifically enumerated statutes (CERCLA, RCRA, Clean Water Act, Clean Air Act, and state equivalents) rather than this catch-all approach. The current broad language could potentially capture minor regulatory guidance that creates technical violations. However, given the written notice limitation in the main representation, this is a lower priority modification.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all federal, state and local laws, rules, statutes, directives, binding written interpretations, binding written policies, ordinances and regulations relating to the environment
risk_inventory.title: Broad Environmental Laws Definition May Expand Liability
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider narrowing to principal statutes only if renegotiating.

risk_inventory.description: This representation only confirms that Seller has provided access to Licenses and Permits 'to the extent in Seller's possession or control.' This is favorable to Seller as it does not warrant completeness, validity, or transferability of such licenses. Seller has no liability for licenses that exist but are not in Seller's possession.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This representation is appropriately limited from Seller's perspective. Maintain the qualifier 'to the extent in Seller's possession or control.' Resist any Buyer requests to: (1) warrant that all necessary licenses and permits have been obtained; (2) warrant that such licenses are valid, current, or transferable; (3) warrant that the Property is in compliance with all licensing requirements; or (4) remove the possession/control limitation. The current formulation is strictly a disclosure obligation, not a compliance warranty.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to the extent in Seller's possession or control
risk_inventory.title: Licenses Representation Appropriately Limited to Possession
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Maintain this limited scope; favorable to Seller.

risk_inventory.description: This representation that Seller is not a foreign person under IRC Section 1445 is standard and required for FIRPTA compliance. It is necessary to avoid withholding requirements at closing. Seller will be required to deliver a FIRPTA affidavit at closing per Section 11.4.5.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a standard and necessary FIRPTA representation. No modification is recommended. However, ensure that Seller can accurately make this representation before execution. If Seller is a disregarded entity, confirm that the tax owner is not a foreign person. This representation should be consistent with the FIRPTA affidavit required under Section 11.4.5.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller is not a foreign person under Section 1445 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986
risk_inventory.title: FIRPTA Representation is Standard and Necessary
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Standard provision; confirm accuracy before signing.

risk_inventory.description: This representation that no person has any right of first offer or right of first refusal is absolute and unqualified. Unlike other representations limited to Seller's knowledge or receipt of written notice, this is a flat representation. If any such right exists in recorded documents or agreements that Seller's deal team is unaware of, Seller could be in breach despite good faith.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider modifying this representation to add a knowledge qualifier consistent with other representations in this Agreement. Suggested revision: 'To Seller's Knowledge, no person has any right of first offer or right of first refusal to purchase the Property, or any portion thereof, arising through Seller.' Alternatively, limit the representation to rights 'created by Seller or contained in the Leases' to exclude any rights that may have been created by prior owners and were not disclosed to Seller. Review all Leases for ROFO/ROFR provisions before confirming this representation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No person has any right of first offer or right of first refusal to purchase the Property, or any portion thereof, arising through Seller
risk_inventory.title: Unqualified ROFO/ROFR Representation Lacks Knowledge Qualifier
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding 'To Seller's Knowledge' qualifier.

risk_inventory.description: This representation speaks 'As of the Closing Date' rather than as of the Effective Date, meaning Seller is making a forward-looking representation about a future state of affairs. If an unexpected party claims possession rights before closing (e.g., adverse possession claim, holdover tenant dispute), Seller could be in breach through no fault of its own. This representation survives closing per Section 5.4 and creates ongoing exposure.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This representation should be modified to limit Seller's risk for circumstances beyond Seller's control. Consider the following revision: 'As of the Closing Date, to Seller's Knowledge, there shall be no tenants with a right to possession of any portion of the Property, except for the Tenants under the Leases described on Exhibit J attached hereto, tenants under leases approved by Buyer under Section 7.3, or parties whose claims to possession arise after the Effective Date through no act or omission of Seller.' This protects Seller from breach due to third-party claims that materialize between signing and closing. Review Section 5.3 regarding reaffirmation of representations at closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: As of the Closing Date, there shall be no tenants with a right to possession of any portion of the Property, except for the Tenants under the Leases
risk_inventory.title: Closing Date Representation Creates Future Compliance Risk
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add qualifier for tenants 'to Seller's Knowledge' or claims arising after Effective Date.

risk_inventory.description: This representation incorporates Exhibit J (the lease schedule) by reference. Any inaccuracies in Exhibit J could cause a breach of this representation. Seller should verify that Exhibit J is complete and accurate before execution.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Before execution, conduct a thorough review to ensure Exhibit J accurately lists all current tenants and occupants of the Property. This should include a review of: (1) all executed leases; (2) any license agreements granting occupancy rights; (3) any month-to-month tenancies; (4) any subleases of which Seller is aware; and (5) any pending lease negotiations that may result in executed leases before closing. Also verify consistency between this representation and Section 5.1.15 regarding Leases.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except for the Tenants under the Leases described on Exhibit J attached hereto
risk_inventory.title: Representation Depends on Accuracy of Exhibit J
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Exhibit J is complete and accurate before signing.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that 'All of the Leases are in full force and effect' is made without any knowledge qualifier. This is an absolute statement that could expose Seller to liability even for matters Seller could not reasonably know about, such as undisclosed tenant claims or technical defaults unknown to Seller's property management.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the sentence to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, all of the Leases are in full force and effect.' This limits Seller's exposure to matters actually known to Seller and is consistent with the knowledge qualifier already applied to tenant defaults in the same paragraph.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All of the Leases are in full force and effect.
risk_inventory.title: Absolute Representation on Lease Status
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

risk_inventory.description: The statement 'There are no uncured landlord defaults or breaches' lacks any knowledge qualifier, unlike the tenant defaults representation in the same sentence. This asymmetry creates strict liability for Seller regarding any landlord default, even technical or unknown defaults that property management may not have disclosed to Seller.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, there are no uncured landlord defaults or breaches, or uncured tenant defaults or breaches, under the Leases.' This applies the knowledge qualifier uniformly to both landlord and tenant defaults.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: There are no uncured landlord defaults or breaches
risk_inventory.title: Absolute No Landlord Defaults Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier for consistency.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that rent rolls 'are true, correct and complete in all material respects as of the date thereof' applies to all rent rolls provided, potentially including preliminary or outdated versions. This could create liability for early-stage documents that were superseded by updated rent rolls closer to closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'The rent roll to be provided pursuant to Section 7.4 below shall be true, correct and complete in all material respects as of the date thereof and identify all Leases in effect as of such date.' This limits the representation to the final, updated rent roll rather than all interim versions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The rent rolls provided to Buyer pursuant to this Agreement (including the rent roll(s) to be provided pursuant to Section 7.4 below) are true, correct and complete in all material respects as of the date thereof
risk_inventory.title: Rent Roll Accuracy Without Time Limitation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit representation to the final rent roll delivered at closing.

risk_inventory.description: The absolute representation that there are no other 'licenses, or other agreements to occupy or use' the Property beyond the Leases lacks a knowledge qualifier. This could expose Seller to liability for informal arrangements made by property managers or historic agreements that may have been overlooked.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, there are no leases of space in the Property, licenses, or other agreements to occupy or use all or any portion of the Property, which will be in force after the Closing other than the Leases.' Alternatively, add: 'other than as disclosed in the Due Diligence Materials.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: There are no leases of space in the Property, licenses, or other agreements to occupy or use all or any portion of the Property, which will be in force after the Closing other than the Leases.
risk_inventory.title: No Occupancy Agreements Beyond Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier or limit to Seller's records.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that Seller is not party to any lease brokerage agreements except those on Exhibit M is stated absolutely without a knowledge qualifier. Seller could be exposed to liability for old or forgotten commission agreements, especially if the Property was previously owned by others or managed by third parties.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Except as disclosed in Exhibit M attached hereto ("Commission Agreements"), to Seller's knowledge, Seller is not a party to any lease brokerage agreements, leasing commission agreements or other agreements providing for payments of any amounts for leasing activities or procuring tenants with respect to the Property or any portion or portions thereof...'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Except as disclosed in Exhibit M attached hereto ("Commission Agreements"), Seller is not a party to any lease brokerage agreements, leasing commission agreements or other agreements providing for payments of any amounts for leasing activities or procuring tenants with respect to the Property
risk_inventory.title: Absolute No Brokerage Agreements Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

risk_inventory.description: The language that commissions 'have been or shall be paid in full' creates an ongoing obligation through closing. Combined with Section 7.3, this could create ambiguity about which commissions Seller remains responsible for if new leasing activity occurs between signing and closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'all leasing commissions and brokerage fees accrued or due and payable under the Commission Agreements with respect to the Property as of the Effective Date have been paid in full or will be paid by Seller at or prior to Closing, subject to the provisions of Section 7.3.' This creates clarity about the temporal scope and cross-references the leasing cost allocation provisions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all leasing commissions and brokerage fees accrued or due and payable under the Commission Agreements with respect to the Property as of the date hereof have been or shall be paid in full
risk_inventory.title: Commission Payment Obligation Through Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that this applies only to commissions accrued as of Agreement date.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that there are no contracts binding on Buyer after Closing except Leases, Permitted Exceptions, and Assumed Contracts is stated absolutely without a knowledge qualifier. Seller could face liability for contracts entered into by property managers, service providers with auto-renewal provisions, or historic agreements not in Seller's active files.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, there are no contracts or other agreements with respect to the Property which will be binding on Buyer after the Closing other than the Leases, the Permitted Exceptions, and the Assumed Contracts.' This is consistent with the knowledge qualifier applied to defaults in the second sentence.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: There are no contracts or other agreements with respect to the Property which will be binding on Buyer after the Closing other than the Leases, the Permitted Exceptions, and the Assumed Contracts.
risk_inventory.title: Absolute No Binding Contracts Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'To Seller's knowledge' qualifier to this representation.

risk_inventory.description: The absolute representation that 'Seller has no employees' and that there are no employment-related agreements affecting the Property is made without any knowledge qualifier. This creates strict liability if any employment arrangements exist through property management companies, building engineers, or other personnel who might be deemed employees under various legal tests.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'Seller has no employees at the Property, and to Seller's knowledge, there are no employment agreements, union agreements, benefit agreements, pension plans, or collective bargaining agreements at or otherwise affecting the Property to which Seller is bound which will survive the Closing or for which Buyer will be responsible for or have any obligation or other liability for after the Closing. Personnel providing services at the Property are employed by the property manager or other third-party contractors.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller has no employees, and there are no employment agreements, union agreements, benefit agreements, pension plans, or collective bargaining agreements at or otherwise affecting the Property to which Seller is bound
risk_inventory.title: Absolute No Employees Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add knowledge qualifier and carve-out for property management arrangements.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that 'the Due Diligence Materials are true and correct in all material respects' is extraordinarily broad. Due Diligence Materials typically include third-party reports, tenant-provided information, historical records, and other documents over which Seller has no control. This creates potential liability for inaccuracies in documents Seller did not prepare.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to read: 'To Seller's knowledge, the Due Diligence Materials prepared by Seller or its agents are true and correct in all material respects. Seller makes no representation or warranty regarding the accuracy or completeness of third-party reports, tenant-provided information, or other documents not prepared by Seller that are included in the Due Diligence Materials.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To Seller's knowledge, the Due Diligence Materials are true and correct in all material respects and do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading.
risk_inventory.title: Broad Due Diligence Materials Accuracy Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit representation to documents prepared by Seller only.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that Due Diligence Materials 'do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading' imposes a securities-law-type disclosure standard that is extremely broad for real estate transactions. This could be interpreted as requiring disclosure of every potentially material fact.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Delete the phrase 'and do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading' entirely. The no fraudulent concealment language in the first sentence already addresses intentional withholding, which is appropriate. The broader no-omissions language creates an unmanageable disclosure standard.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: do not omit any fact or circumstance necessary to make the statements contained therein not misleading
risk_inventory.title: No Omissions Representation Creates Expansive Duty
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete or narrow the no-omissions language.

risk_inventory.description: The knowledge definition is favorable to Seller as it limits knowledge to only two named individuals (Robert Martinez and Jennifer Williams) with no duty of inquiry and no imputation of knowledge. This is a protective provision for Seller. However, Seller should verify that these are indeed the correct individuals with primary responsibility for property matters, as naming individuals who lack actual knowledge could create issues if a Buyer later claims the wrong people were named.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is favorable to Seller. No changes needed unless client wishes to add additional knowledge parties or confirm the named individuals are appropriate. If modifying, ensure any additions maintain the 'no duty of inquiry' and 'no imputation' protections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: without duty of inquiry or imputation of knowledge
risk_inventory.title: Knowledge Definition Appropriately Limited
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm named individuals are correct and have property knowledge.

risk_inventory.description: This provision creates an affirmative obligation on Seller to give notice to Buyer of any change in condition or any changed condition that would make representations inaccurate. This duty to disclose could be interpreted broadly and creates ongoing monitoring obligations for Seller between signing and closing. Failure to provide such notice could be characterized as a default or breach.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the notice obligation to apply only to 'material' changes: 'Unless Seller gives notice to Buyer of any material change in the condition of the Property subsequent to the Effective Date or of any other material changed condition that would make any of the representations or warranties in Section 5.1 materially inaccurate, incomplete or misleading'. This prevents triggering notice obligations for immaterial or de minimis changes.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Unless Seller gives notice to Buyer of any change in the condition of the Property subsequent to the Effective Date or of any other changed condition that would make any of the representations or warranties in Section 5.1 inaccurate, incomplete or misleading
risk_inventory.title: Affirmative Duty to Disclose Changes
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding 'material' qualifier to notice obligation.

risk_inventory.description: This provision grants Buyer a termination right with full deposit return if any representation becomes inaccurate, even for changes outside Seller's control. This is a significant risk as it essentially creates a broad walk-away right for Buyer based on changed circumstances, market conditions, or third-party actions that affect representation accuracy. The 5-day window is short, but the right itself is very broad.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to limit Buyer's termination right: 'In the event any of the foregoing Seller's representations and warranties become materially inaccurate due to circumstances within Seller's reasonable control, then Buyer may elect to either (i) terminate this Agreement and receive a full return of the Earnest Money Deposit by giving Seller written notice of such termination within 5 Business Days after Buyer received notice of such material inaccuracy (with the Closing Date extended to accommodate such 5 Business Days period), or (ii) proceed with the Closing with knowledge and acceptance of such facts. For changes outside Seller's control that render representations inaccurate, Buyer's sole remedy shall be to proceed to Closing or terminate without the return of the Earnest Money Deposit.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may elect to either (i) to terminate this Agreement and receive a full return of the Earnest Money Deposit by giving Seller written notice of such termination within 5 Business Days after Buyer received or delivered notice of such inaccuracy
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Termination Right for Rep Changes
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Limit termination right to material changes within Seller's control.

risk_inventory.description: The carve-out providing Buyer 'all rights and remedies for default' when changes are 'within Seller's control' is vague and could be interpreted broadly. What constitutes 'within Seller's control' is subjective and could lead to disputes. Additionally, granting 'all rights and remedies' could be interpreted to include specific performance or consequential damages beyond the caps in Section 5.4.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to clarify the scope: 'if such Seller's representations and warranties are no longer accurate due to Seller's intentional or grossly negligent acts (as opposed to market conditions, tenant actions, governmental actions, or other third-party conduct), then, subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 and Section 13.1 below, Buyer shall have available to it the remedies set forth in Section 13.1 for Seller default.' This ties the remedy to the default provision and clarifies what 'control' means.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: if such Seller's representations and warranties are no longer accurate due to reasons or causes within Seller's control, then, subject to the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 below, Buyer shall have available to it all of the rights and remedies for default and Seller's breach
risk_inventory.title: Full Remedies for 'Within Control' Changes
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Define 'within Seller's control' and clarify remedy limitations apply.

risk_inventory.description: The 12-month survival period for representations and warranties is relatively standard and favorable to Seller. Many buyers push for 18-24 months. This provision adequately protects Seller's interest in finality.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No changes needed. This is a seller-favorable provision with a reasonable survival period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall survive for a period of 12 months from the Closing Date
risk_inventory.title: 12-Month Survival Period is Reasonable
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Provision is favorable; no changes recommended.

risk_inventory.description: The $25,000 deductible/threshold and the cap of greater of $1,000,000 or 5% of Purchase Price are reasonable protections for Seller. These provisions effectively limit Seller's exposure to representation breaches.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No changes required. If client wishes to further limit exposure, consider reducing the cap to the lesser of $1,000,000 or 3% of Purchase Price, though this may face buyer resistance.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: under no circumstances shall Seller be liable to Buyer on account of any breach of any representation or warranty in the aggregate in excess of the amount equal to the greater of (i) $1,000,000 and (ii) 5% of the Purchase Price
risk_inventory.title: Liability Cap Structure is Favorable
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Provision is favorable; consider if cap should be lower.

risk_inventory.description: Both the deductible and the liability cap expressly exclude attorneys' fees. This means Seller could face uncapped liability for attorneys' fees in connection with representation breach claims, which could significantly exceed the stated cap in contentious litigation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Remove the attorneys' fees exclusions to ensure the cap applies comprehensively: '(a) Buyer shall not make a claim against Seller for damages for breach or default of any representation or warranty, unless the amount of such claim is reasonably anticipated to exceed $25,000; and (b) under no circumstances shall Seller be liable to Buyer on account of any breach of any representation or warranty in the aggregate in excess of the amount equal to the greater of (i) $1,000,000 and (ii) 5% of the Purchase Price, inclusive of all attorneys' fees, costs, and expenses.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: excluding attorneys' fees
risk_inventory.title: Attorney Fees Excluded from Cap
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Include attorneys' fees within the liability cap.

risk_inventory.description: Section 6 introduces Buyer's representations but does not include parallel limitations to those protecting Seller in Sections 5.3 and 5.4 (such as survival periods, deductibles, and caps). This creates an asymmetry where Seller's claims against Buyer for representation breaches may be unlimited while Buyer's claims against Seller are capped.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a new subsection after Section 6.6 (or at the end of Buyer's representations): '6.7 Survival and Limitations. Buyer's representations and warranties shall survive Closing without limitation as to time or amount. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the limitations set forth in Section 5.4 shall not apply to any breach by Buyer of its representations and warranties hereunder.' Alternatively, if symmetry is preferred, reference Section 5.4 mutually.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: 6.	BUYER'S REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES.  Buyer represents and warrants to Seller, as of the Effective Date and as of Closing, the following:
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Reps Lack Parallel Limitations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm Buyer's reps have unlimited survival or add parallel caps.

risk_inventory.description: Buyer represents it is a Delaware LLC in good standing, but there is no requirement that Buyer qualify to do business in the state where the Property is located (Washington, based on context). If Buyer is not qualified in Washington, this could create enforcement issues or complications at closing.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to include foreign qualification: 'Buyer is a limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of Delaware and is qualified to conduct business in the State of Washington (or will be so qualified prior to Closing).'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer is a limited liability company duly organized and validly existing and in good standing under the laws of the State of Delaware
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Delaware LLC Status
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add requirement for Buyer to be qualified in Property state.

risk_inventory.description: This provision explicitly acknowledges that Buyer may not yet have internal authorization to proceed to Closing at the time of contract execution. While Buyer represents it will obtain such authorization before issuing the Buyer Approval Notice, this creates significant risk for Seller. If Buyer fails to obtain internal approvals during due diligence, Buyer can simply decline to issue the Buyer Approval Notice and terminate the agreement, effectively using the due diligence period as a free option period while Seller's property is tied up. This is a one-sided arrangement that favors Buyer.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to require Buyer to have obtained all necessary internal authorizations prior to execution of this Agreement, or alternatively, add a specific shorter deadline (e.g., 10 Business Days) by which Buyer must confirm receipt of all internal authorizations, independent of the Due Diligence Period. Consider adding that failure to obtain such approvals by the specified date constitutes a Buyer default entitling Seller to the Earnest Money Deposit.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: although Buyer is authorized to enter into this Agreement, Buyer may only be authorized to issue the Buyer Approval Notice and proceed to Closing if and when it receives additional internal authorizations during the Due Diligence Period
risk_inventory.title: Buyer May Lack Closing Authorization
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to confirm full authorization at signing or provide shorter approval period.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'additional internal authorizations' is undefined and entirely within Buyer's control. Buyer could claim it needs investment committee approval, board approval, partner consent, or any number of internal hurdles that Seller cannot verify or influence. This gives Buyer excessive discretion to terminate during the due diligence period based on purported failure to obtain unspecified internal approvals.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a requirement that Buyer must identify in an exhibit or schedule all specific internal authorizations required to proceed to Closing, including the authorizing body, expected timeline, and criteria for approval. Add language stating that Seller shall have no liability and the Earnest Money Deposit shall be forfeited if Buyer fails to obtain internal approvals that were not disclosed at signing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: additional internal authorizations
risk_inventory.title: Undefined 'Internal Authorizations' Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Require Buyer to identify all required internal approvals in the Agreement.

risk_inventory.description: This section references 'Section 6.1.2 above' for an exception to the consent representation, but the Buyer's Representations section appears to start at 6.1 (Status) without a subsection 6.1.2. This creates ambiguity about what consents may actually be required and could allow Buyer to claim undisclosed consent requirements exist as an exception.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Confirm whether Section 6.1.2 exists in the final document. If not, either (a) delete the phrase 'Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above' so that Buyer's representation is unqualified, or (b) insert the correct section reference. If the reference relates to Buyer's authorization contingency in Section 6.2, consider whether this exception undermines the consent representation entirely.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above
risk_inventory.title: Reference to Non-Existent Section 6.1.2
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify correct cross-reference or delete the exception entirely.

risk_inventory.description: The reference to Section 6.1.2 suggests there may be consent requirements that Buyer has not yet obtained. Combined with the internal authorization language in Section 6.2, this could mean Buyer has multiple outs from the transaction. Seller should understand exactly what consents remain outstanding.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a requirement that Buyer must disclose in writing all consents, waivers, approvals or authorizations that have not yet been obtained, including from any lenders, investors, partners, or internal governance bodies, and the expected timeline for obtaining each.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Except as noted in Section 6.1.2 above
risk_inventory.title: Potential Undisclosed Consent Requirements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Request Buyer to disclose all outstanding consent requirements.

risk_inventory.description: The OFAC representation extends to 'any of their respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners' which may include passive investors or fund participants that Buyer cannot fully verify. While this representation is standard, Buyer may resist if it has complex ownership structures. This is generally favorable to Seller as drafted.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This provision is generally favorable to Seller. If Buyer requests a knowledge qualifier, resist or limit any qualifier to only those equity holders owning more than a specified threshold (e.g., 10% or 25%). Ensure that the representation extends to the full ownership chain to the extent reasonably knowable by Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: nor any of their respective partners, members, shareholders or other equity owners
risk_inventory.title: Broad OFAC Representation Covers Unknown Parties
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm representation is acceptable; consider adding knowledge qualifier resistance.

risk_inventory.description: Seller must obtain Conforming Tenant Estoppels covering 80% of leased square footage plus ALL Major Tenants as a condition to Buyer's obligation to close. This is a high threshold that gives Buyer significant leverage and potential exit opportunities if any Major Tenant fails to return an estoppel or returns one with any inconsistency. Seller has no control over tenant cooperation, yet bears the risk of transaction failure.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise to reduce the estoppel threshold from 80% to 70% of leased square footage. Add language permitting Seller to deliver a Seller-executed estoppel certificate in lieu of a tenant-executed certificate for non-Major Tenants if the tenant fails to respond, with Seller representing the accuracy of information therein. Consider adding a materiality threshold for what constitutes a 'Nonconforming' estoppel.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Receipt of Conforming Tenant Estoppels (as defined below) from the Major Tenants (plus a sufficient number of other Tenants under Leases so that Buyer receives Conforming Tenant Estoppels for Leases covering at least 80% of the currently leased square footage
risk_inventory.title: High Estoppel Threshold Burden
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Reduce threshold to 70% and allow Seller-executed estoppels for non-Major Tenants.

risk_inventory.description: Buyer has broad termination rights if Seller cannot cure estoppel inconsistencies. Combined with the low threshold for what constitutes a 'Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel' (any material matter inconsistent with Due Diligence Materials OR Seller's representations), this gives Buyer substantial ability to exit the transaction late in the process without penalty if market conditions change.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify the definition of Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel to require that the inconsistency be 'materially adverse to Buyer's interest in the Property' and involve either (a) a rent reduction exceeding $X annually, (b) an unscheduled termination right, or (c) landlord obligations exceeding $X. Add language that minor or immaterial inconsistencies shall not give rise to termination rights and Buyer must accept such estoppels as Conforming.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer, as its sole remedy therefor, may elect to either: (i) postpone Closing one time for up to 14 days to allow Seller to attempt to accomplish such cure, (ii) terminate this Agreement, in which event the Earnest Money Deposit shall be returned to Buyer
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Termination Right for Estoppel Issues
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add materiality threshold and limit termination to issues exceeding defined dollar thresholds.

risk_inventory.description: While Buyer can terminate for Nonconforming Estoppels, if Buyer elects to close despite the inconsistencies, there is no purchase price reduction. This seems protective of Seller but actually creates perverse incentives - Buyer is more likely to terminate rather than negotiate a resolution because closing means accepting the issue at full price.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add an option (iv) that allows Buyer and Seller to negotiate in good faith a purchase price reduction reflecting the economic impact of the inconsistent matter, with the adjustment amount to be mutually agreed or, if not agreed within 5 Business Days, either party may elect termination or proceed at the original Purchase Price.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: close the transaction regardless of the inconsistent matter(s) disclosed in the Nonconforming Tenant Estoppel(s) (in which case they shall be treated as Conforming Tenant Estoppel(s)) without a reduction in the Purchase Price
risk_inventory.title: No Price Reduction for Estoppel Issues
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider allowing negotiated price adjustment as alternative to termination.

risk_inventory.description: Buyer has 10 Business Days to object to draft estoppel certificates or they are deemed approved. However, Seller must deliver drafts within 10 Business Days of Effective Date. This front-loaded timeline may not allow Buyer sufficient time to review all lease files and identify issues, potentially resulting in estoppels going out with errors that later become Seller's problem.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider extending the estoppel draft review period from 10 Business Days to 15 Business Days to ensure Buyer has adequate time to review all lease documents and provide comprehensive comments, reducing the risk of Nonconforming Estoppels arising from drafting oversights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be deemed to have approved the draft estoppel certificates unless it objects to specific errors or omissions within 10 Business Days after receipt thereof
risk_inventory.title: Short Estoppel Draft Approval Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Extend Buyer's review period to 15 Business Days for complex portfolios.

risk_inventory.description: Seller must 'immediately' deliver copies of any tenant correspondence regarding claims, defaults, or non-routine communications. The term 'immediately' is vague and operationally burdensome. It could be interpreted strictly to mean same-day delivery, which may be impractical and could create technical defaults.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Replace 'immediately' with 'within 3 Business Days after receipt' to provide a clear, reasonable timeframe that is operationally achievable while still keeping Buyer informed of material tenant communications.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall immediately deliver to Buyer a copy of any correspondence received from any Tenant regarding any claims of default or requests for action by Seller or Seller's property manager or other non-routine communication
risk_inventory.title: Immediate Correspondence Delivery Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'immediately' to 'within 3 Business Days' for operational clarity.

risk_inventory.description: Seller cannot enter into any new leases or amendments without Buyer's written consent. While consent cannot be unreasonably withheld, this restriction applies from Effective Date through Closing, which could be several months. If a valuable leasing opportunity arises and Buyer is slow to respond or raises unreasonable objections, Seller could lose the opportunity.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language stating: 'If Buyer fails to respond to a request for consent within the 5 Business Day period specified herein, Buyer shall be deemed to have approved such lease or modification.' Also consider adding specific criteria for what constitutes 'reasonable' grounds for disapproval to reduce disputes.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall not enter into any new leases or amendments to any current Lease nor waive performance of any Tenant's obligations under its Lease without Buyer's written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed
risk_inventory.title: Broad Lease Approval Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add deemed approval after 5 Business Days of non-response to lease requests.

risk_inventory.description: Buyer has only 5 Business Days to disapprove a proposed lease or modification before deemed approval occurs. While this is protective of Seller's ability to conduct business, Seller should be aware that this deemed approval mechanism means Buyer may approve leases that later create complications at closing if they were not thoroughly reviewed.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: No change recommended - this deemed approval provision is favorable to Seller. However, Seller should implement internal procedures to track the 5 Business Day periods and document delivery of lease proposals to Buyer to preserve the deemed approval rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall notify Seller in writing of its disapproval with an explanation of its objections thereto set forth in reasonable detail within 5 Business Days of Buyer's receipt of a copy of the proposed lease or lease modification, or Buyer shall be deemed to have approved the same
risk_inventory.title: Short Lease Approval Response Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Current language is favorable; ensure tracking system for approval deadlines.

risk_inventory.description: The provision states Buyer shall bear all Leasing Costs related to amendments, modifications, extensions, expansions, options or renewals approved during the contract period. This is favorable to Seller, but Seller should ensure the Leasing Costs are clearly documented and credited at closing to avoid post-closing disputes.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add clarifying language: 'Seller shall provide Buyer with reasonable documentation of any Leasing Costs incurred in connection with such approved amendments, modifications, extensions, expansions, options or renewals no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing, and the parties shall include appropriate credits and allocations on the closing statement.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Closing occurs, Buyer shall bear all Leasing Costs related to any amendments, modifications, extensions, expansions, options or renewals of the Leases in accordance with Section 7.3
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Bears All Leasing Costs on Amendments
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify documentation requirements for Leasing Cost credits at closing.

risk_inventory.description: The definition of Leasing Costs is quite broad, including 'any out-of-pocket payments' that are 'in the nature of a tenant inducement' with a non-exhaustive list. This broad definition could potentially capture costs that Seller did not anticipate would be credited to Buyer, though the 'including specifically, but without limitation' language does provide some guidance on intended scope.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding clarifying language: 'Leasing Costs shall not include (a) normal operating expenses of the Property, (b) repairs or maintenance required under the Lease regardless of when the obligation arose, or (c) costs for which Seller is entitled to reimbursement from the tenant.' This prevents normal operating costs from being characterized as Leasing Costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any out-of-pocket payments required under a Lease to be paid by the landlord thereunder to or for the benefit of the tenant thereunder which is in the nature of a tenant inducement, including specifically, but without limitation
risk_inventory.title: Broad Leasing Costs Definition
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding exclusions for normal operating costs vs. true tenant inducements.

risk_inventory.description: Seller represents and warrants that Exhibit L sets forth ALL Leasing Costs still outstanding. This is an unqualified representation that could create liability if any Leasing Costs were inadvertently omitted from the exhibit. The representation should be knowledge-qualified to match the standard for other Seller representations.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Modify to read: 'Seller represents and warrants that, to Seller's Knowledge, Exhibit L attached hereto sets forth all Leasing Costs still outstanding under those Leases in effect as of the Effective Date.' This aligns the representation with the knowledge standard used elsewhere in the Agreement and prevents strict liability for inadvertent omissions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller represents and warrants that Exhibit L attached hereto sets forth all Leasing Costs still outstanding under those Leases in effect as of the Effective Date
risk_inventory.title: Seller Representation on Existing Leasing Costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add 'to Seller's knowledge' qualifier to the Leasing Costs representation.

risk_inventory.description: Seller must deliver the statement of Existing Leasing Costs paid 'no later than 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date.' This is a tight timeline that may create last-minute closing complications if there are discrepancies between the statement and Exhibit L, particularly for a complex property with multiple tenants.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider changing 'No later than 5 Business Days' to 'No later than 10 Business Days' to provide adequate time for Buyer to review the documentation and for the parties to resolve any discrepancies before Closing without causing closing delays.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No later than 5 Business Days prior to the Closing Date, Seller shall deliver to Buyer a statement, with reasonable supporting documentation, of the Existing Leasing Costs actually paid by Seller between the Effective Date and the date of delivery of such statement
risk_inventory.title: Late Documentation Deadline for Leasing Costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider extending to 10 Business Days to allow time to resolve discrepancies.

risk_inventory.description: Buyer only assumes responsibility for Existing Leasing Costs 'up to the amount of the credit that Buyer received at Closing.' This means if there are Existing Leasing Costs that were not on Exhibit L or that exceed the credit amount, Seller may remain liable. This provision should be cross-referenced with the representation above.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider revising to: 'Buyer shall assume responsibility for paying all remaining Existing Leasing Costs as set forth on Exhibit L (as such exhibit may be updated by mutual agreement prior to Closing).' This removes the cap tied to the credit amount and ensures Buyer assumes all scheduled obligations. Alternatively, add language that any Existing Leasing Costs not listed on Exhibit L shall remain Seller's responsibility only if Seller had actual knowledge of such costs prior to Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall assume responsibility for paying the remaining Existing Leasing Costs up to the amount of the credit that Buyer received at Closing
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Assumption Limited to Credit Amount
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit L is comprehensive; consider uncapped assumption by Buyer.

risk_inventory.description: New Leasing Costs allocation uses the Due Diligence Deadline as the dividing line. This is appropriate, but Seller should be aware that leases entered into between Effective Date and Due Diligence Deadline (even if approved by Buyer) would have their Leasing Costs treated as Existing Leasing Costs under Section 7.3.2, requiring Seller credit.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Consider adding clarifying language: 'For the avoidance of doubt, Leasing Costs for any new Lease entered into between the Effective Date and the Due Diligence Deadline with Buyer's approval (or deemed approval) shall be treated as New Leasing Costs and shall be Buyer's responsibility.' This shifts the cost allocation to Buyer for any deals Buyer approved during due diligence.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be responsible for the payment of all Leasing Costs payable for (a) any new Leases entered into after the Due Diligence Deadline that have been approved (or deemed approved) by Buyer
risk_inventory.title: Due Diligence Deadline Reference for Leasing Costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify treatment of leases approved between Effective Date and DD Deadline.

risk_inventory.description: For non-transferable letters of credit, Seller is obligated to provide 'reasonable cooperation' to Buyer and the tenant after Closing to facilitate reissuance of a new letter of credit. This creates an open-ended post-closing obligation for Seller with no time limit, no cap on the extent of cooperation required, and could involve ongoing administrative burden. While the parenthetical excludes expenditure of funds, the cooperation requirement itself could be time-consuming and extend indefinitely.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the sentence to add a reasonable time limitation on Seller's post-closing cooperation obligation. Suggested revision: 'shall provide reasonable cooperation to Buyer and the applicable tenant for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days after Closing (but without the need for expenditure of funds or more than de minimis administrative effort) to facilitate the reissuance of a new letter of credit to replace the letter of credit previously held by Seller.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall provide reasonable cooperation to Buyer and the applicable tenant (including after Closing, but without the need for expenditure of funds) to facilitate the reissuance of a new letter of credit
risk_inventory.title: Unfunded Ongoing Cooperation Obligation for Non-Transferable LOCs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add time limit (e.g., 90 days post-closing) for cooperation obligation.

risk_inventory.description: While Buyer has no duty to collect delinquent rents, Buyer is required to bill tenants for delinquent rents for 6 months after Closing. This creates a situation where Seller is dependent on Buyer's good faith performance of billing obligations to collect pre-closing arrears. There is no remedy specified if Buyer fails to bill properly or in a timely manner, potentially impairing Seller's ability to collect amounts owed.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add language providing Seller with recourse if Buyer fails to bill tenants as required. Suggested addition after the first sentence: 'Buyer shall provide Seller with copies of all billing statements sent to Tenants for delinquent rents within ten (10) Business Days of sending. If Buyer fails to bill Tenants as required herein, Seller shall have the right, upon written notice to Buyer, to directly bill such Tenants and Buyer shall reasonably cooperate with Seller's collection efforts.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall be required to bill Tenants for delinquent rents in the ordinary course of business for 6 months after Closing
risk_inventory.title: Six-Month Billing Requirement Extends Seller's Dependence on Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add remedy or recourse if Buyer fails to properly bill tenants.

risk_inventory.description: The payment application waterfall applies payments: (a) first to the month of Closing, (b) second to Buyer's period of ownership, and (c) third to Seller's period of ownership. This structure subordinates Seller's pre-closing delinquent rent claims to Buyer's post-closing claims. If a tenant is chronically delinquent, Seller may never receive payment for pre-closing arrears as new delinquencies will take priority.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Revise the payment application waterfall to apply payments in chronological order, which would benefit Seller for pre-closing arrears. Suggested revision: 'such payments shall be applied (a) first toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) for the actual month in which Closing occurred, (b) second toward the oldest outstanding delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) chronologically, allocating between Seller's and Buyer's respective periods of ownership accordingly, unless the Tenant designates the payment for a specific period.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (a) first toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) for the actual month in which Closing occurred, (b) second toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) owed to Buyer for its period of ownership and (c) third toward the delinquent rent (or other tenant charge) owed to Seller for its period of ownership
risk_inventory.title: Rent Payment Waterfall Subordinates Seller's Pre-Closing Claims
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise waterfall to prioritize oldest delinquencies first.

risk_inventory.description: Seller's reserved right to pursue remedies for delinquent rents is limited by the prohibition against terminating any Lease or Tenant's right to possession. While this is a reasonable protection for Buyer's asset, it limits Seller's collection leverage for pre-closing delinquencies and may make collection impractical for significant arrears.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is a market-standard provision protecting Buyer's tenancies, but Seller should be aware of the limitation. If Seller has significant pre-closing delinquencies with particular tenants, consider negotiating a specific carve-out or addressing the delinquency as a Purchase Price adjustment at Closing rather than relying on post-closing collection rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: but shall not be entitled to terminate any Lease or any Tenant's right to possession
risk_inventory.title: Seller Cannot Terminate Lease or Possession for Collection
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider whether this limitation is appropriate for your transaction.

risk_inventory.description: The updated rent roll must be delivered no sooner than 10 Business Days and no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing. This creates a 5-Business-Day delivery window that could be operationally challenging if Closing is accelerated or if there are administrative delays in compiling accurate rent roll data.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: This is an informational risk for Seller's awareness. Ensure property management has processes in place to generate updated rent rolls within this window. If operationally challenging, consider negotiating a wider window: 'No sooner than 15 Business Days prior to Closing and no later than 3 Business Days prior to Closing.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: No sooner than 10 Business Days prior to Closing and no later than 5 Business Days prior to Closing
risk_inventory.title: Short Window for Rent Roll Delivery Before Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure internal processes can meet this delivery window.

risk_inventory.description: Seller retains responsibility for 2025 Reconciliation Statements, including responsibility for tenant overpayment refunds and audit costs, with an express survival provision but no time limit. Tenant audit rights often extend 2-3 years under leases, meaning Seller could face claims for reconciliation errors or audit costs years after Closing with no cap or limitation.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a reasonable time limitation on the survival of these obligations. Suggested revision: 'The provisions of this Section 7.7 shall survive the Closing for a period of twenty-four (24) months or, if longer, until the expiration of any applicable Tenant audit rights under the Leases with respect to 2025 operating expenses, but in no event longer than thirty-six (36) months after Closing.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The provisions of this Section 7.7 shall survive the Closing.
risk_inventory.title: Unlimited Survival for Reconciliation Obligations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add survival period limit aligned with tenant audit rights in leases.

risk_inventory.description: Seller is obligated to pay tenant overpayments and audit costs related to 2025 reconciliations without any cap or limitation. In a multi-tenant property with significant operating expense pass-throughs, errors in the 2025 reconciliation could result in substantial refund obligations. Additionally, multiple tenant audits could generate significant costs with no aggregate limit.
risk_inventory.model_instructions: Add a cap on Seller's aggregate liability for reconciliation-related payments. Suggested addition: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller's aggregate liability for overpayment refunds, underpayment credits against delinquent rent, and audit costs under this Section 7.7 shall not exceed [$ amount or percentage of Purchase Price], and any amounts in excess thereof shall be Buyer's responsibility.' Alternatively, tie this liability to the overall representation and warranty cap in Section 5.4.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall promptly remit such overpayment to the Tenant
risk_inventory.title: No Cap on Seller's Reconciliation and Audit Cost Liability
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider capping reconciliation liability or tying to representation survival cap.

risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Contracts' includes 'leasing, brokerage' agreements.
